												A great variation on the classic game Oregon Trail. Instead of heading west to start new cities and find Fame/Fortune, you are trying to escape the Zombie apocalypse  and reach Safe Haven.The game is about resource management and does a great job of staying true to the original, with fun variations. You travel with 4 friends in a crappy station wagon. Your car can be upgraded and repaired with spare parts when it breaks down. You can scavenge for food while avoiding and shooting zombies. And ofcourse Random things happen while on the Road, some bad and some funny.Overall a fun game.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Hahaha, get it? It's like Oregon Trail, but...No, it really is Oregon Trail with zombies. But instead of being a one-note joke, Organ Trail actually improves on the original formula in significant ways. If you somehow never encountered an Apple IIe in school, the basic idea of ______ Trail games is that you have a party of 4 or so travelers on their way to a distant destination. Random things happen on the way, sometimes you get a choice to make, other times not. Settlements give you the chance to shop, barter, or scavenge for supplies. Organ Trail sets this up as you and your 4 pals escaping D.C. in a beat-up station wagon, carrying as much food, ammo, car parts, and fuel as you can. In addition to the random horrible things that happen, you'll also encounter minigames like dodging zombie deer and motorcycle gangs on the highway, or making a clutch shot to save a friend from a kidnapper. These interactive events really help break up the monotony of watching your beater roll down the highway while bad things happen to you all.Settlements are where the game really shines, because there are a wealth of options for managing your journey. In terms of supplies alone, you can buy and sell for cash, wait for trade offers on your goods, scavenge by playing a little top-down action minigame, and do side missions (also minigames) to get paid in goods. There are additional options for managing the health of your team, for maintaining and upgrading your ride, and even learning new special skills for your player character that help in minigames. Learning how much you need of what resources and what upgrades you should spring for can take time, so be prepared to either lose a few times or start on Easy. The first time I picked this game up I got rather frustrated because my car broke down and I got trapped in a settlement with no way to repair it. But after a few more rounds I learned the power of scavenging and practiced my minigaming and now everything runs smooth... on Normal, anyway.It's a pretty deep game for a literal Oregon Trail clone, and the zombie aspect fits the style well without being tired. There are some cute pop culture references that are clever enough not to annoy, and plenty of replay value. As long as the ultra low-res graphics and learning curve don't put you off, this is a grand little coffee break game.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Organ Trail's pretty damn fun. It's essentially Oregon Trail with zombies and a bunch of Left 4 Dead references. I had the iOS version before buying the Steam version, and I feel like the game's easier to control on a computer as far as shooting goes. That being said, shooting is still a ♥♥♥♥♥ as far as controls go, and it's difficult to nail on the head. Some of the in-game passersby even acknowledge the problems with the controls by stating, "These controls suck!" (They do.) But having a mouse removed the issue of my finger blocking parts of the screen. The writing is often times humorous and references things from the original game to Castlevania. It gives Organ Trail a certain charm and unusual atmosphere. Some of the locations throughout the game are rather humorous as well (one of these being--I kid you not--a strip club), and it gives me the impressions that the developers made this purely for fun, which I find admirable. It's always nice to find a game that convinces players that the people who made it definitely had a kickass time doing so.I've noticed that, while the overall gameplay is generally difficult (even on normal), it gets progressively harder as you move further down the map, which I found reasonable, in my opinion. That being said, it's very good at screwing you over, as nothing's worse than wasting half your food and all your time stuck on the side of the road trading away for enough scrap so that you can attempt a repair on the car that ultimately fails, causing you to waste all your scrap. That actually happened to me. It's not fun. However, to an extent, the game is as difficult as your are good at strategizing and planning a course of action. You will blame yourself many times for the mistake you've made. Many times, crises can be avoided or worked around if you're prepared enough. Yet, given this, random events still occur, and if the odds aren't in your favor, you could end up doing well to being dead in a few miles. It's always important to be cautious in this game as a result.The music is also spot-on as well. Amidst all of the humor and gags, it gives Organ Trail a more solemn tone. Also, it's generally interesting to listen you and combines an 8-bit feel with a more "advanced" (if that's the word) sound to it. I don't quite know how to explain it. But it's really well done, in my opinion.The graphics are also very charming and reminiscent of the original games. They work really well. Not sure what else to say here. I like them a lot.Also, the Clement's Quest minigame is hilarious. It's essentially a TL;DR Organ Trail where you control the car and run over zombies as quickly as you possibly can. I discovered it on accident and couldn't have been happier that I did.Basically, to put it bluntly, despite the game's difficulty, I really enjoy this game and always have a good time while playing it. It was worth purchasing it the second time, and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants a challenge and a nostalgic, yet new take on a classic.

Posted: March 9, 2015
AUDIONeo-RetroVISUALCommodore 64DIFFICULTYLuck, ModerateVIBESomberCRAVINGSim, ManagementON SALEInfrequentlyPROS: Oregon trail made with a zombie twist. It plays just about the same as the original game did, making it an extremely fun play. It demands a combination of skill, foresight and luck in an environment that changes often, giving this game high replay value. Shooting and escape segments control surprisingly well, and random events feel a bit more balanced than in its predecessor.CONS: Zombie shtick is very tired. There is virtually no educational value in this, which I felt was half the fun of the original! The game assumes you are familiar with Oregon Trail, so if you are new to this there may be a slight learning curve in properly managing your resources. WORTH: A single game does not take very long to get through, less than half an hour. However, one or two playthroughs is not what Organ Trail is about. You could easily get 30 hours out of it, especially if you do completionist play. $5.00 is a very fair price for it.OVERALL: This isn't Oregon Trail exactly, but I'm happy there is some version of it on Steam complete with achievements, cards, twitter options and online leaderboards. It blows Super Amazing Wagon Adventure out of the water and is the current go-to to satisfy this nostalgic desire. SCORE:8/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013



YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Organ Trail 

			Views: 2,183		

			Today, Analog Reviews looks at Flash game turned indie hit Organ Trail By Senior Reviewer Trent Follow us at https://twitter.com/analogreviews Leave your comments below and like and subscribe if you...		

	The Men Who Wear Many Hats originally created Organ Trail as a flash game and after some fund raising they were able to release an expanded version of their original title on mobile devices and now PC. Organ Trail takes it's primary inspiration from the original Apple II iteration of The Oregon Trail and opens with your character encountering Clement, a fellow survivor who kick-starts your odyssey across a post apocalyptic United States. Much like the game it parodies, Organ Trail is about balance. You will need to ensure that your party is fed, rested and your car in tip top mechanical condition. With every mile that ticks by your parties health degrades as well as your trusty station wagon. Injury and disease are common occurrences on the road as evidenced by the many tombstones that can be encountered on your journey. These tombstones are not only reminders of the peril that face your party but also opportunities for upgrades and supplies. Party members can be bitten on your voyage and may require a euthanizing rifle blast to the head. Of course, if you are a misanthropic sociopath you could always off your healthy party members and not have to worry about keeping them fed and healthy. Dotting the trail to safety are landmarks and cities that allow your party to trade, buy and sell items, upgrade your car and purchase perks for your character. You can also take on jobs to earn some cash or supplies and chat the locals up for information. Scavenging is often the easiest way to stay supplied on your journey. By opting to scavenge an open field pops up with random items spawning. Little green zombies home in on your character as you attempt to scoop up scrap for car repairs, food for nourishment, and cash for additional supplies. It's possible to defend yourself from the zombie onslaught while scavenging with a rifle. You must click and pull your mouse back which brings up a line of site on the screen which you can then spin while in a fixed position to dial your site in on the revolting rotting flesh heaps that converge on your position. Releasing fires and these controls take a bit of time to acclimate yourself to. A couple of seconds to reload between each round ensures a bit of tension as you scramble for goodies. Bosses are also randomly encountered on these scavenging excursions. They are more robust creatures that put up a bit more of a fight than your average walking corpse. The jobs that are on offer use variations of these mechanics. Some require you to defend a position by taking cover and killing zombies before they reach your position, some have you locating an item in a scrolling field while zombies swarm and the last variant has you trading gun shots with others humans in fortified positions. These mini games can feel repetitive after a while since your character doesn't receive new weapons and enemy types are limited. The randomness of these events will keep you coming back however. Also, random encounters with biker gangs and hordes of zombie deer mix things up while in your station wagon. Random interactions with other travelers on the road also spice up the core game and offer a little bit of narrative. Prompts will appear that ask if you feel inclined to investigate something on the road. Doing so kicks off an old school adventure sequence that often results in a reward of some sort. This touch adds quite a bit of re-playability to Organ Trail. While the randomness of Organ Trail ensures a new experience every time it can  also lead to frustration. It's not uncommon for tragic events to occur in quick succession and take out a party member or even your party leader. It can be upsetting, perhaps off putting for some, when a well supplied and positioned expedition fails because of a bout with dysentery and broken ribs...  Ultimately Organ Trail: Director's cut is one of the best games to emerge from the zombie zeitgeist that has gripped popular culture over the past half decade.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												I'm going to recommend this game, even though it has it's share of problems and I'm mad at it. If you enjoyed Oregon Trail growing up, and like zombies, you'll find this game worthwhile. I have two general problems with the game though. My first problem is that the achievements are very buggy. Playing through the game multiple times over for an achievement turns from fun to horror when the achievements reset. My second problem is that once you figure out how the game works, it gets boring. Basically, theres generally an 'optimal' way to play it and once you know how, the game becomes less fun because you know exactly what to do in each situation...there are no more surprises. I mean, in the 15 hours I played I learned the more-or-less "right" things to do and got ranked in the mid 300s on the global leaderboards for a playthrough. I didn't feel particularly skilled at the game, just that I followed the obvious rules. Anyway, still fun for a few playthroughs. Get it on sale.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												I spent many an hour in my elementary school computer lab playing Oregon Trail, we always felt like our class had won the lottery because we got to play video games in school! I know it was supposed to be secretly educational, but looking back I learned nothing of any value playing it. Regardless, I loved every minute of it.I picked up Organ Trail for something like 27 cents (I don’t remember the exact amount but it was low enough that I could recoup the loss by picking up change in a parking lot) and when all was said and done I got exactly what I expected of it: a silly, over the top interpretation of the classic Oregon Trail formula. I bought supplies, hunted zombies instead of the buffalo/duck hunt mini game, repaired my station wagon as opposed to an ox drawn wagon, and had everyone in my party die of the same disease as my settlers did all those years ago.If you’re looking for a quick, silly re-imagining of Oregon Trail you would not regret picking Organ Trail up in a sale.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
The walking dead simulatorOrgan trail is unique 2D Rogue-like management game with zombies. The gameplay is this game's main highlight. Before you start your game, you get to name your character as well as your group members. It is generally advised that you name group members based on people you love/hate (famous people etc) as it will make the experience more interesting as you watch how long they last. After that you get to choose the types of items you will carry along with you like feul, food, money etc. You begin your journey in your station wagon traveling to the next city. Along your travel you may face some random encounters which may affect the game e.g. losing items, more vehicle damage, random stop, members getting sick etc. As you travel you will also consume fuel. Should you run out of feul you can either scavange some or spend time waiting for someone to come along and trade you some. Scavenging involves collecting resources while fending off zombies with your gun. Aiming with you gun is terrible (which isn't surprising because this is basically an android port) as it involves clicking and draging to where you want to shoot and then missing most of the time (It takes a while to get used to basically). When you reach towns you can talk to survivors, take side quests which involves fending against zombies or bandits (which gives you resources as rewards), buy/sell supplies (fuel, food, ammo), heal the group as well as repairing and upgrading your station wagon. Like feul food is also depleted as you travel. You have the option of rationalising the consumption of food. Should it be depleted you and your other survivors will gradually lose health until they die. You also have an option to kill any of you party members at anytime, should you no longer require their company. You basically move from city to city surviving the zombie apocalypse as much as you can until you reach the sanctuary. Should you die, the game immeditaely ends and you are taken back to the main menu to begin a fresh run again if you wish. The game is quite challenging and addicitve so you will play this game a several times. The music adds to desloate atmosphere. Whether your in a town, traveling or hunting you get to experience a spooky and lonely soundtrack which helps to instill the feeling of trying to survive a zombie apocalypse. The weapon sounds aren't that great.There isn't much story to the game. Basically the intro starts you off with meeting some survivors. You formulate a plan to get to the sanctuary (city free of zombies) and begin your journey together in the station wagon.The graphics aren't that great. They do an OK job at presenting a dark atmosphere, but they lack detail.If you want a resource management rogue-like game with zombies and don't min wonky shooting controls, this game will appease your interests.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Instead of going to Oregon to stake a claim on America's future, you decide the fate of a group of survivors looking for a safe place to live in a post-apocalyptic world overridden by zombies.  You travel from Washington DC, that's about to be nuked, all the way to a safe haven in, you guessed it, Oregon.  The game is faithful in every way it can be to the Oregon Trail, except where it could be made more thematically appropriate to a zombie apocalypse, with multiple additions to improve the simulation and theming.  Seriously, name a feature from Oregon Trail and it's there.  Dysentary?  Check.  Bad water?  Check.  Tombstones?  Check.  You get the picture.Oregon Trail's 'hunting' minigame, being the best part of the original, has become a bit more central to the experience with Scavenging and Jobs using it, with a few others including Defense, Surrounded and Bandit Raid events using the same shooting mechanics.  When Scavenging, you no longer shoot a 2000 pound buffalo to carry back 100 pounds of meat.  Instead you rummage around a wilderness, collecting any supplies that pop up (including food, cash and scrap that you can use to repair your car), while avoiding and shooting zombies that swarm in on you.  Learning to control the flow of these zombies to reduce the amount of ammo I have to spend was a fun mechanic to master (no doubt aided by my recent experience with Gauntlet), and I must say, is probably the best way to ensure your victory at the game. In a funny way, Organ Trail is one of the most complete zombie apocalypse simulations I've played, and if you like the genre, you really should play it just because it's a fun game.  If that's not enough to attract you, maybe the novelty of recreating the Oregon Trail experience on a modern platform with a modern genre is enough.  I would happily recommend Organ Trail even at the premium price of five bucks.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												It's The Oregon Trail, but with zombies. And Clements. And zombies. And shotguns. And scavenging for food and supplies. And zombies. And dysentery. And references. And zombies. And biker gangs. And... did I mention it has zombies?In all seriousness, this is a really fun parody of The Oregon Trail. You lead a party of four other survivors in your quest to safe haven, all while fending off zombies, scavenging for food and supplies, dealing with dysentery, fending off biker gangs and undead fauna, and wondering how exactly one would break their leg inside a station wagon. Campaign Mode is your quest to Safe Haven, while Endless Mode lets you travel forever (so long as you maintain your supplies and pray that none of your party members survive) while completing challenges that unlock new presets and buffs that add replayability to the game. If you always thought The Oregon Trail was missing zombies, then this is the game for you.

												Organ Trail is nothing short of a fun realization of the old classic with the tried and true zombie twist.At first glance it's easy to scoff at this game and even write it off, but presentation shouldn't fool you. Once in the game, none of that will matter as the solid gameplay, comedy aspect, and nature of the genre take hold of you. You'll be crossing fingers as you push through the hordes hoping they don't take notice. The scavenger side missions are also gratifying, but the controls are a bit awkward, making it more of a flustering challenge than maybe it warrants.After a few runs, things get a bit repetitive, but that's the nature of the game. It's no short haul to make it across country and there's plenty in between that'll you need to survive. I would definitely recommend playing this if you havent, and especially if you are old enough to have enjoyed the original Oregon Trail.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												What to say about Organ Trail?It's Oregon Trail, re-upped and zombified. If you like the Oregon Trail, get this. If you didn't like the Oregon Trail, you will not like this. If you don't know what Oregon Trail is, or are neutral towards it, I'll explain.Organ Trail replaces the covered wagon of its inspiration with a station wagon, fills it up with a couple people you will inevitably name after either fictional characters or real-life friends and family, and then tasks you with getting them across the country alive. This is easier said than done, this being the zombie apocalypse and all, and you'll need all the meager help you can get.The game is based more on tactical decision-making than it is on high-octane gameplay, though there are more than a few tense moments. Everything about Oregon Trail is now zombie-related: you're attacked by zombies instead of bears (or zombie bears), instead of fording a river the highway is covered in zombies, instead of dysentary you get dysen-- okay that one stayed the same, but the other ones are different.The biggest draw that I still feel to this game is its approach to your "leadership" to the group. At any time, you can choose to execute one of your friends. They get no replacement, you're essentially shooting yourself in the leg here and hurting your chances of making it to the end. The main reason why you would ever do this is if they've been infected. It's a tough choice to make, and the game doesn't just let you get away with hitting the "kill them" button and  moving on. You have to wait until you're all sitting around a campfire, hit the button to shoot them, and then, in a game dominated almost entirely by menus, you are taken to a small cutscene of you holding a gun to the person you intend to kill. They don't resist, they don't say anything, they just stand there. The game doesn't let you just get rid of them, you have to look them in the eyes and pull the trigger yourself, then watch their body slump to the ground in front of you. It's far more powerful than it has any right to be, especially on a more intense, serious run where you've begun to get attached to your party.The game isn't perfect, though. Its general replayability is high, but its brevity means that you'll probably be spent after about 6-7 runs, which will take around 10 hours or so.The weakest point of the game is the finale; it's a final, incredibly tense mission, where success means victory and failure means back to square 1. Without giving anything away, I'll just say it's not terrible, but it definitely could have been done better, especially when it comes to how it handles your remaining allies.Overall? I think this game is worth the price if you're a fan of the source material, and if not, then it's still worth the sale price.7/10 seems fair. A modest recommendation. Oh, and there IS a Flash version online, so check that out if you want to know what you're getting into before you buy.

content:
Posted: February 14
LITTLE JOHHNY has died of dysentery.Organ Trail: Director's cut is a parody of The Oregon Trail edutainment games, and a significantly enhanced version of the original browser game.Instead of needing to colonise the promised land of Oregon, your task in The Organ Trail is to lead your ragtag bunch of misfits, or whoever survives it anyway, to the safety of, well, Safe Haven. Conveniently located across the entirety of the United States, in Oregon. Reason being that the US is nuking cities overrun by zombies, which happen to include all of the East Coast, where you start.True to its origins, it's displayed as an Apple ][ game, with 8 bit sprites and bleeps and bloops for sound effects. The music is damn good though.Like in The Oregon Trail, you must manage your dwindling supplies and grueling pace across the long journey. Unlike in The Oregon Trail, there's a lot more game in this game. Random events still pop up across your journey in a station wagon (hue), but are less frequently going to instantly cull one of your gang. Scavenging plays a big part in keeping your food supply high, but it's a hazardous endeavour in the 45 second long bit of gameplay an hour of scavenging is condensed into. In a bit of a twist, money remains important for buying resources in settlements and cities, and for upgrades on your character or your car, despite the zombies. Across your trek through the USA, you must monitor your party's condition, which is impacted by the size of the food rations, and your station wagon's integrity, which goes down faster if you're pushing it to 60mph. Every in-game hour of travel your party stops to rest and do other things - including breaking legs (lampshaded in a random passerby's dialogue), finding some food, sitting too hard on a fuel can or 4 and ruining them, or, infamously, contracting cholera, which just makes them lose health faster. At every stop you can check their condition, opt to rest and regain health, apply medkits to quickly heal, or put them down for any reason, or for no reason. You also get random events: your gang may be taken hostage by raiders and you need to carefully aim to kill the bad guy without doing in your friend too, or just kill them both you sicko; you have to cross a horde of zombies by either waiting for them to become docile, or going guns blazing; dodging ravenous zombie deer or ramming into biker raiders; and special encounters with people who might need your help.Most importantly, the tombstones are a thing, and they are absolutely hilarious. You can leave your own tombstone when you die, too, and then you can come across it again in a separate run. oh boy what a great dayThe base game offers a very healthy selection of content, and while the base gameplay loop doesn't change across runs, random events and the degree of refuge in audacity certainly do. If you like what it has on offer, the Final Cut DLC is absolutely worth it: roughly double the content, and adding new stuff like choosing what route to take, with pros and cons, dealing with radiation poisoning if you go for the risky but time saving paths, extra skins for your character, extra vehicles to play in, and a couple other smaller things here and there too!But what doesn't change is your party's predisposition to break limbs randomly at stops.

												This game takes the Oregon Trail games and mixes it with The Walking Dead. This game will immediately tug on your nostalgia factor, for those guys and girls out there that grew up in the 90s like myself (being born in the 90s doesn't count as growing up in the 90s). Nostalgia factor aside, I don't think I can recommend this game. The thing that ruins my nostalgia was the pacing of the game. There wasn't enough going on to keep my interest. The only reason I played for so many hours was to get the achievements, which is another complaint altogether. It's just tedious grinding. AND ITS SOOO DREARY AND SLOW. The zombies in the game move faster than the actual game itself. The game is clever and funny, very tongue in cheek. However, I cannot recommend this game, because after one TEDIOUS and UNNECESSARILY long play though, you will have gotten the gist of the game. Honestly, anything after the first play through is dull and uninspired. And to me, one enjoyable play through does not warrant a "must buy."

												Ah a great refreshment game to burn some hours! And Organ Trail is a good place to start. Firstly, one of the best things about this game is that it doesn't try to be more than what it is, a zombie-remake of the classic Oregon Trail. It has it all, stocking up, fording the zombies, scavenging for goods, surviving attacks, hanging in towns. You truly never know what could happen! content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Zombie slaughtering and survival doesn't get any more ghetto than this.  Your main quest is to survive a journey from one side of the U.S. to the other, with four other survivors, with one clunky shotgun, and with your only vehicle to make this journey being a station wagon with wooden side panels.  That's right.  You have the freedom to kill the survivors with you at any time, thereby saving on fuel and food in the long run.  You'll have to scavange for food and fuel with a sh-tty shotgun.  You can catch malaria, or die of dysentry at any time.  Someone could get bit, maybe that someone is you.  At any time, the bit someone could turn around and bite anyone in your group.  If you don't put them down, you might get bit too.  It's only you that needs to make it to the end to win the main game mode.  While driving, you could get runned down by a pack of zombified deer, or a rogue motorcycle gang.  Even though you can run over the gang, or get mauled by deer, or drive through clustered gangs of zombies, all many times during your journey--in the end, the wooden side panels on your station wagon remain shiny and unscathed as if still brand new.  Bring Chuck Norris along for a fuller pimped-out effect.Truly, zombie survival gaming doesn't get any more ghetto than this.

number of helpful: 68 of 128 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2013
												This is a parody of the old classic Oregon Trail, but with a zombie twist to it. The real selling point seems to be that parody. You start out as a party of 5 and work your way from Washington DC headed west. It is a supply and demand sort of game where when you start, you buy your supplies, then at times you'll run low whether it is med kits, fuel, batteries, food or ammo. How do you get more? You stop and trade, scavenge or doing odd jobs.Organ Trail is broken up into cities that have places to buy and sell things. They'll also have either combat training or auto repair shops where you can buy mufflers, batteries, tires or upgrades. You can also fix your car at the shops. If you don't have the cash to repair your car, you can always use scrap, but using X amount of scrap only gets you X percentage the repair will be successful. Like 2 scrap will be 20% successful.If you can't make it to a city, you can stop at any time to repair your car, scavenge, rest for health regeneration, kill infected party members and use med kits. I seemed to find traders more frequently when I stopped outside of a city. When you scavenge, make sure to pay attention to what the game tells you the zombie activity is. More zombies, more problems. The jobs also tell you the risk factor, anywhere from normal to suicide. Just make sure the reward is worth the risk and play it safe.The game is full of mini games. Scavenge has you slowly running around a screen dodging zombies, collecting random things. Sometimes the game will bust out a boss to chase you that is far more difficult to avoid than the zombies. When scavenging, you don't even need to shoot, so much as run and avoid. There are defense mini games that require you to stay put and shoot either zombies or bandits. The shooting feels very imprecise and has you clicking on a zombie with your mouse and dragging it back to your character to aim, then releasing the mouse button to fire. There are a lot of misses even with what looks like a perfectly aimed shot.There is a mini game where your station wagon gets chased by a biker gang and you need to run them off the road and there is even a mini game where you dodge reindeer chasing after your station wagon. After you complete Organ Trail, it will unlock a Clemons mini game that has you driving a station wagon left going up triangle hills, jumping off and ramming zombies in a side scroller.When you are on the road, random events happen, such as your characters breaking bones, getting diseases, being mugged, losing items, finding graves, wading through zombies, helping people, looting bodies, injuring your entire party and so much more. Its all text for the most part.After you complete the game, it unlocks an endless mode. The interesting part of endless mode are the modifiers, such as your party can start out infected or they are deep sleepers and recover twice as fast. The sad thing is endless mode is really endless, and I just don't like the thought of being able to play Organ Trail forever.Even with all of the random events that make every playthrough different, it felt like a chore having to scavenge so much. It was as if the scavenging was the bulk of my play throughs. I didn't find it fun. The random events are really just that, random and rarely benefit you, which is why its more of a supply and demand game. Everything is designed to drain you, but then you need to compensate for it. Please just skip this game, it looks cool, it sounds cool, but there aren't moments of 'yay I did it!' so much as moments of 'how would hitting a bump in the road lose 2 med kits?' Oh well.

number of helpful: 24 of 43 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												The game does what it sets out to do--create a version of the classic Oregon Trail game, but with zombies. There's some neat nods and references to other zombie franchises out there, and it captures the feel of the original game pretty well while still having its own identity.That being said, it also reminded me how boring the original Oregon Trail really was. Although there's a few neat scenarios and moral conumdrums this is mostly a resource-management game with a few very basic zombie-shooting minigames involved (that have controls that are a little frustrating to deal with). If you play the game for too long it can get pretty repetative, particularly when you hear the same dialogue over and over.Admittedly part of my disappointment might be because the version of Oregon Trail I grew up with was Oregon Trail II, which had some pretty campy FMV stuff in it but had more stuff to do overall and felt like a fuller game. I'm also getting a little bored of zombies at this point and Organ Trail doesn't attempt to do anything new. So I'm definitely coming at this game with a bias. It's not a BAD game, just one that I ultimately felt "meh" on once I finished it.If you have a lot of nostalgia for the original or just can't get enough of zombies, there's definitely far worse games you could pick up, particularly at the price point. But don't expect anything too surprising, the game more or less plays out the way you'd expect, so if you're on the fence I'd maybe wait for a sale or get something else instead.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												I love this game way more than I could put into words. Simple design, easy access, addicting. I would call it a "retro survival sim": a zombie apocalypse ended the world as we know it. You and your friends try to cross what once was the USA from the East Coast to the West, chasing a rumor known as "Safe Haven", a stronghold where the zombie outbreak seems to have been controlled. Your job is to admin everything until you reach Safe Haven, that is gas, money, routes, including scavenging for food, at what hours you should best do so, keeping an eye out for your ammo, deciding if you should keep going to the West Coast with your bitten friend or if he is a potential menace to the whole group and should be rather put down, if you should risk breaking your car driving for another mile in the hopes of finding a better trading spot, etc., etc. These tasks may appear mundane at first, but once you soak in the rather dark atmosphere and realize how close you have become to those pixels with the name of random friends, the game becomes a tragic story of a group just trying to survive and their everyday trying to do so. And you are the leader. It's so much fun to experience and imagine the situation you go through. One moment you'll think you made a great deal buying that tire for so cheap, the next you'll curse yourself for not having rather invested in scraps. And while on the road, you'll sometimes encounter little "choose-your-own-adventure"-like events with fellow survivors, some friendly, others not so much, spicing up the experience.Organ Trail is impressively immersive, given it's Atari graphics and lack of a deeper canon story. It's one of those video game experiences in which the game only makes the rules, while you make the story in your head, and I think this is the strongest point here.But as good as it is, it has some very nasty bugs that can bring you serious frustration. For example, I just was at the end of the game, a comrade died and the game refused to advance until I fed all of them to the zombies. As if this wasn't enough, the game got stuck after defeating the final boss. After having spend my time carefully administrating my crew from coast to coast through hordes of zombies, this wasn't a rewarding pay off. I just wish such issues were patched already, since they happen relatively often with me, let's say, every 3rd or 4th playthrough.Be it as it is, though, I can only recommend Organ Trail as a fantastic game for those who like just make up and imagine their own zombie stories while playing along.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												I usually really hate these fake retro games, especially ones with a "twist" like this, but I really like this game. The good thing about this game is that it is actually fun to play and it doen't just rely on the fake retro style for nostalgia. I am one of those people who grew up playing Oregon Trail in the computer lab at school (although the version I was familiar with was a later version of the game that this is based on) and this game does a good job recreating the feel of the original, and it actually improves on it. But this game is not simply a re-make of Oregon Trail either; although it is based on that game, it is also a new game itself.I think it is definitely worth its price because it is fun and has a great replay value.

												Anyone who's played the original Oregon Trail game, or any of its remakes, will know vaguely what this game is like. Fun, long, and difficult. What they won't know, however, is how much better this game is than the original. It is an improvement not just because of the zombie aspect and the nostalgic graphics, but also because of the constant Chuck Norris jokes and the subtle oddity of the strange abundance of car parts owned by absolutely everyone you meet, and yet the sudden dissapearence of the one you need just when you need it.As said earlier, this game is harder than it looks, as there are CONSTANT random events that will, more often than not, impede your progress to the Safe Haven. However, this means that, each time the game is played, it will be totally different from any other time.This game is a neverending supply of both fun and frustration, and, in my opinion, worth the purchase.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The game looks simple but that doesn't mean the game is fun. It is hard though and you need some luck here and there.The game takes you through a small tutorial at first and lets you get used to the controls. The rest you have to figure out yourself. What is usefull and what not, what is the best option to do, ect.It's based off an old game called Oregon Trial. But in here there are zombies and there are some things changed and added. It isn't a long game but it is fun to replay the game and try other ways to beat it and harder difficulties.The graphics are old styled. Since the game where it was based off is also in the same sort of style. But in here it looks a bit better. If you aren a graphics kind of person then don't pick the game up. From the screenshots you see on the store page.. That's all you will get.The soundtrack is quite nice. If you get annoyed by it after a few times of playing it, you can always put on your own music.It doesn't cost much and it's worth picing up if you enjoy a bit of hard and a bit of luck based games. If you don't mind how the game looks like that is. The game is also available for the Android and IOS. If you want to play it everywhere. I find the controls a bit better on there since you have to swipe instead of dragging your mouse. But it is a personal prefrence.Get it when you can if you like what you see and read. And if you think the price is too high then wait for a sale. Though getting it for the IOS and Android would also be a good choice.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												They just took him. Grabbed him from the back seat of the car and took him. Sure, he was annoying at times. He lost more cash than he ever earned, and somehow got himself shot by a stray bullet, but Sketch was one of us y'know? Us survivors have to stick together. So I picked up my rifle and stepped out of the car. I didn't have much choice. I wasn't going to leave him behind. Ottah hadn't looked good for some time since the first Z he saw took a chunk of him. Sleepy got bitten soon after. As for Rabid, I'm pretty sure she was high the whole time. She never got ill, never caused a problem. I forgot she was there most of the time.So, there I was. It was an old fashioned stand-off. The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ was hiding behind Sketchy, holding a pistol to his head. I didn't need to think. I just shot. 


I'm a hero. Praise me. 
A Screenshot of Organ Trail: Director's Cut
By: C.




From that moment on, there was no turning back. Anyone who stood between my guys and Safe Haven, dead or alive, I took them out.It was tough, but we made it. All of us made it. Hopefully Ottah and Sleepy will be able to live with the bites. As for me, there are more survivors out there and someone needs to help them ...That was the story of my first adventure in Organ Trail. I foolishly played on Easy, which I wont be doing again, as once I learned my way around the game it wasn't very challenging. I guess I'm too used to recent roguelikes murdering me on my first turn! (I'm looking at you FTL)I always get an extra kick out of games where I can name multiple members of a party. Naming the characters after my buddies helped me grow attached to them. Or hate them for constantly being ill (Ottah!) or a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥(Sketch!). The shooting took a little to get used to, but it was okay once I got the hang of it.As for replayability, Endless Mode offers up unique starting scenarios and there are a fair few of them. I'll be making a start on those real soon!The sound style matches the graphics, but I'll happily play this on mute and listen to my own music. It's not a problem with the style of the music, I just find it to be quite bad. Also, I'm sure I heard a dodgy distorted version of the 'Happy Birthday' tune at some point.The most important thing I have to say about Organ Trail, is that I want to play more. As soon as I finished the game, I wanted to play again. That's the sign of good gameplay. Organ Trail doesn't have fancy graphics to fall back on. All it's can offer is its solid gameplay. If you're a fan of survival games, and don't mind the design this is something that you should pick up.Bottom Line: Organ Trail is fun and leaves you wanting more.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Could this game be fun? Yes.  Is it fun? NoI get what they are trying to do with this game, but the lack of tutorials within make it just flat out annoying considering it is a rogue like.  There are a ton of different encounters, but with the pixelated graphics and practically zero instructions on how to do any of them, you are bound to fail over and over again which usually means the death of a party member.  Given that you can't go back on any of this, it often means that you have to scrap your play-through and start over from the beginning just so you can maybe learn the controls for that particular event, blah.I like the idea of a rogue like game that follows a group over a long stretch of road that is riddled with random encounter and so on, but it would be nice if you were given some idea of what you  are supposed to do before the encounter or how the controls even work.After starting over for the 3rd time because I lost a party member to lack of instruction,  I got fed up.Leave this game alone

Posted: May 24, 2015
												good piece of retro survival! The gameplay is simple but fun, and the original's Oregon Trail painful aspects (keyboard aiming for an example) have been scraped out. The game has many secrets and unique finds, aiming for a good replayability factor, but these events are so rare (i only came across 2 in 8 full gameplays, when the game says there are over 15) that you won't experience everything this game has to offer. The game is also a bit too short. There are many, many events and possibilities, but the trailer's makes one believe that this will be also a psychological battle against yourself, with many moral dilemmas and such,  when the largest one you will find is pressing a button to kill one of your crew.6.5/10 ,only purchasable because its cheap , but not for everyone.

Posted: March 13, 2014
												AUTHOR NOTE.While i have only a few Minutes on this game, i have played it and beaten it multiple times on a Non-Steam Version.The Best Oregon Trail Zombie Simulator, Ever.Literally, when i saw this title i was surprised by its atmosphere. The Music is a factor but so is the music. I feel like people are being eaten, things are bleak and grim in this chaotic outbreak spanning across mainland america. The game ultimately is extremely bleak and sometimes even masochistic at times, even gameplay. I mean seriously, what other game do you have where you get a choice between marrying a bride to her groom's corpse or to put her out of her misery and blow her brains out? I felt like a Devil playing this game, offing each of my members to get to my location. I felt like my Car constantly was breaking down and we had nowhere to run, even when we stopped by to examine the dead in their graves! (Which is pretty stupid, i mean why would you do that. Would make sense if it was the graves of your fellow team but its not.)The Gunplay is literally Apple 2 esque, you "draw" the line you want to shoot with your mouse, it takes alot of getting used to but its a mechanic chosen well, otherwise this game's combat would be very easy. You also walk at a SNAILS Pace while running from zombies, and should judge the distance of the undead with which location you should go. Juking the Zombies, its been done similar in other games and remains a interesting mechanic that makes it much easier to survive the combat portions of Organ Trail. Also the wages you get paid are ridiculous and the difficulty ratings are extremely intimidating initally, the higher ones are defintely not to be taken lightly and i'd recommend wasting a few peons on it to get used to the missions because your not getting money any other way besides taking jobs. Money is so important, i cannot unstate how much ive seen my own people die because ive been a few dollars short of a medkit or my entire car fall to pieces in a few miles. Its rage inducing but there is something in Organ Trail that i see in Risk of Rain almost, where in that i just NEED to find a way to make it all work. Its that which makes it all the more devastating or victorious when you actually Win or Lose in this game. Its hilariously cheap, to a level that i think it personally doesn't deserve but i come back to this title every now and then for another ride on the amazing organ trail.TL:DR?Fun but Nigh on Masochistic. Gameplay takes learning.Defintely a great title to get at the price. Recommended.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												This game is a survival game, set in a zombie world (how original :D) To be honerst I accualy liked this game very much, it was a bit of a surprise, that I had heard many bad things about it,The games goal is very simple go form point A to point B, in order to complete the game. You start out with a car, and a team. Along the way you will properly loss team mates, to zombies hunger, desiases and many other things. You have to find food parts and money to survive all the time. This is done by small mini games, that you have to do, in order to continue the game. The game is a bit point and click, but the mini games, makes up for the gameplay.This is not a must buy in my opinion, but it is a fun little game to play, when you have no ideer what you are going to play. This game get`s a thumps up. 4 out of 10

Posted: July 9, 2013
												Organ Trail resembles a certain other game, which I doubt I even need to name. Instead of a wagon, you have a station wagon, and instead of homesteading the west, you are trying to escape the zombie apocalypse... by going west! It might have simple graphics, yet it's fun and challenging. Sadly it does have some boring parts, where you just watch your car move, and terrible things like breaking a battery or someone getting bitten will happen. This makes it very similar to the game with a similar name, where someone will just randomly die of malaria, but the zombie apocalypse setting makes it way better. The resource management is also still there, while instead of hunting for animals, you will be hunting bandits or going for an item while zombies hunt you. Organ Trail is one of those simple games that ends up being pretty awesome. Pimp your ride, ford hordes, survive zombie deer herds, then get your brains gnoshed on by a zombie bear and have to start all over from the beginning... again.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												Depressing, but not quite as depressing as FTL.This is actually a far better game than Oregon Trail, or most zombie games for that matter, because the bad luck can be remedied with good performance in the arcade sequences. There are several, and they aren't afterthoughts. They're actually fun minigames. Unlike the old action interludes they parody, they're designed to frighten and challenge while still giving you a fair shake at success. Despite its appearance, this is a new videogame first and a retro homage last. Its underlying design is sophisticated and graceful.Much has been said about the awkward aiming controls, but they are like some ancient forgotten system unearthed by gaming archaeologists. I got used to them quickly, without ever becoming too comfortable. They add a manageable awkwardness to the combat encounters that I enjoyed.My one objection was the jarring experience of losing outright when my main character died, something I did not expect after finding myself in a groove of what seemed like a classic party adventure. This game feels more like a successor to Might & Magic, Starflight, and indeed FTL than it feels like like a one-joke riff on a piece of pop nostalgia, and I was a little bummed to just have the story end with four of my party still alive. Then again, there's something to be said for never finding out what happened to those guys. It's a little haunting, a bit more of what we fear about death than usually makes it into a game.Two bonus stars for an appropriate and pretty chiptune soundtrack, good production values, modern resolution options, and for somehow being much easier on the eyes than screenshots might lead you to believe.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												An excellent game limited by it's lack of variation and choices.Replayability is very large but long-play-at-once is harmed by lack of variation and repetitiveness. Very fun to try another game at harder difficulties, but if it drags on for too long you eventually become exhausted of the lack of surprises and it's very hard to keep interest. This happened in my first run. Scavenging consists of picking randomly appearing items on a limited map as zombies randomly spawn and get close to you, for 40 seconds. Sometimes you'll need to scavenge many times in a row. Yeah.Music is one of the best i've seen around, a frankenstein composed of chiptune music mixed with real instruments, super capable of conveying the emotions of having to put down your now-8-bit best friend after realizing you weren't going to have enough food to make it to safe haven at this pace.Could have had a lot of variation item wise, and would have been nice to have more things to look at, talking to strangers just consists of a text screen, and you can do it anywhere, even when not in towns. It made you question the solidity of the plot; just how many people are going on the roads at once if you can talk to anybody at anytime? Why is it dangerous then?Once you learn the mechanics it's very, very hard to die. Resting can get over any disease, broken leg, or bullet wound. There's no apparent benefit from keeping your friends  alive other than having extra support at finales and the score multiplier. They won't complain about your choices, you'll never be kicked off being a leader or care too much if someone gets bitten, after all, they won't die if they get bitten unless their health goes really low. Which is prevented with resting a few hours per town. Yeah.Otherwise, the game is really great and the first run you'll be covering your face hoping the scrap you managed to collect before you starved is able to fix your car so you can get to the next town and hopefully buy food. Real tense moments where your hands are tied and you must project into the future to know what to do, maybe Bobby doesn't deserve coming with you guys if he ruined food by sitting on it or throwing your only muffler at a zombie. Or maybe you could sell Karen to cannibals for 250 dollars. Hm. Or you are very wounded but Joe needs the medkit because he's suffering from radiation poisoning and his skin is ♥♥♥♥ing falling off.Gameplay 7/10Music 10/10Graphics 6.5/10 (this is because of the lack of variety, instead of being very low detail, it's supposed to be like that dummy)Overall 8/10It's worth the full price, it's great to pass the time. Although, a friend gifted it to me.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												As a person who's basically addicted to this game with over 100 hours of breaking limbs, getting Dysentry, and playing both Endless and beating the Campaign over. I can clearly say that I love this game. Naming your rag-tag group of survivors after friends, and soon letting yourself be more immersed in the atmosphere and looking past the retro pixel graphics, you got yourself a zombie survival game. It's really a huge part of my own personal fun of how I can imagine and experience my friends or certain people coming along to my ride, going through starvation, infection, bandits, zombies, and the like. With the chores of taking care of supplies, you can go at the game with your own pace, either it be conservative, going at a slow pace while trying to save as much food by starving your party, or much more aggressive/safe where you go as fast as possible, pushing your car to limits, as you give a huge buffet for all your party members to keep them healthy. There are two main modes to the game. There's the campaign mode;moving from Washington D.C all the way to the west coast to your final destination: Safe Haven. Then there's Endless mode, with you going as far as possible in the fastest pace for more points, trying to keep yourself, and (depending on your playstyle.) keeping your party alive. This is honestly a great simple game, with an amazing soundtrack along with lots of events occuring along with RNGesus to dicate a slow-death, or a plentiful gold mine of food, medkits, and other supplies. With the complete edition DLC, all your fun with the game only doubles, now adding extras! Such as even MORE RNGesus to give you more ways to death, a lot more choices in what you do. An amazing parody/redesign to the original Oregon Trail. Every dollar was worth it.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E25 Organ Trail: Director's Cut 

			Views: 78		

			Looking for a great retro game that parodies a classic retro game? Check out Organ Trail! Available on PC and Phones alike!		

Organ Trail: Director's Cut: A retro styled video game that parodies the famous Oregon Trail video game by putting you in a zombie apocalypse where you travel to a Safe Haven in Oregon in a station wagon. Very similar gameplay to Oregon Trail, you'll scavenge or trade for supplies, defend yourself from zombies, humans and evil hordes of deer and other monsters. Encounter random and weird things along the trail and watch your friends break arms, ribs and catch a variety of awful diarrhea disease like a case of classic dysentery. It being a retro game, the graphics are simple color pixel graphics, the sound in the game are also simple with beeps and boops making up all sounds. The music in the game is awesome, its this sort of rock bit music by Ben Crossbones, there is a soundtrack for sale with 22 track, 2 of which are only on the track, I would recommend checking it out for purchase. The game comes with a ton of extras, references to zombies in video games and movies, a Campaign and Endless mode to differentiate your game every time you play, if you don't prefer or enjoy retro games the Organ Trail won't change your mind, but, for everyone else it’s a fun and simple game, play on your phone or with friends and laugh at the horrible things that happen to them. TL/DR: Organ Trail is an awesome zombie game, it references movies and video games alike, and it’s simple enough to play, and it’s even available on your phone! If you don't like retro avoid this game, everyone else should check it out its only $4.99 USD and the soundtrack and the game is only $11.99 USD and laugh as your friends crap themselves to death. Or break legs, whichever.-Thumbs Up from RoyialVideo Reviews: www.youtube.com/RoyialNetwork

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												5/5The most original remake concept I have ever seen!It's hard to sum up the words to describe Organ Trail...  It is Oregon Trail.  If you remember who Ronald Reagan or Ronald McDonald was, you probably played this game in school.  If not, bear with me.Organ Trail still retains the old turn based, town to town survival as the original.  The only real difference is that you are trying to survive while traveling west to escape the Zombie outbreak, rather than seeking fortune.The game is done PERFECTLY, in my opinion.  The music is haunting and the artwork is as smart and lovable as it is creepy.Lots of achievements and extras.  Every time I play I find something different.If you like Zombies... buy it.  If you like Oregon Trail... buy it.  If you like casual, fun games... buy it.  Oh hell, just buy it!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												I first heard about Organ Trail from a youtuber who played the free flashgame version of this game a couple of months back.Later i heard about it from another youtuber who played the version on steam and i really enjoyed how the game looked, so i bought it.So far i don't regret it. The goal of the game is to make it from the east coast of the usa to the west coast. If you take into cosideration that a zombie apocalypse is taking place while you are trying to achieve that, it certainly doesn't make things any easier.The gameplay is simple but really intense: You and 4 other survivors (which you can name however you like) travel in a car from landmark to landmark. On the way from one landmark to another there are various things that can happen: You get robbed by thieves who steal your fuel, someone gets bitten by a zombie, a horde of deers appears behind you and you have to dodge them, someone gets sick, etc. etc.On the landmarks you get the chance to trade with other survivors for food, fuel, medkits, etc. You get to scavenge for supplies, repair your car or get perks from traders.All in all the gameplay is pretty simple, but awfully intense. The fact that you never know what happens on the road and the feeling you get when you are close to the safe haven but you don't know if you can make it because you are low on fuel or food is really nervewrecking and well done.Oh and the graphics and sound are phenomenal. 8-bit awesomeness from top to bottom.I'd recommend this game. The replayabilty is also pretty high, since every run is different and there is an endless mode to sum it all up. It's definitely worth 5 bucks. And if you are not sure, try out the free flashgame on the interwebs.

												This game reminded me of a time when a new game was not a swift download with an App to assist. 												I just beat the game on Suicide difficulty, and now I myself feel like a zombie.This game retains all the RNG-screwage of the original Oregon Trail, but in a Zombie Apocalypse setting. On easier difficulties, the RNG is proportionately generous, but on Suicide it's just egregiously taxing as you're incessantly starved for any and all resources. It's painful.A lot of the achievements are broken and nonfunctional, so definitely stay away from this game if you're an achievement hunter.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												The Organ Trail is based off the other computer game most kids in the 90's played in school.  Cause it was the only game we could actully play in school that the teacher wouldn't yell at us for playing.The graphics are minimal, and I honestly applaud that, to many developers think that they need top notch 3D graphics to make a game fun, when you just need to have fun gameplay.  This game delivers fun gameplay in spades.You start off by picking the names of your companions, so you can sentance people you disilke to die or bring friends with you in spirit, after that its pretty much a zombie road trip, bad things will happen, you can try and prepare for it the best you can, but you are on a road trip cross country to reach a safe haven.The game has plenty of easter eggs, homages, and is just down right awesome, if you love zombie games, and adore indie games you really need to pick this one up for yourself.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2013
												This one took me by surprise. Organ Trail is a old school adventure game where you travel by car, along with 4 of your friends, to a safe place where you're totally free of zombie attacks and other dangers. The art style is retro, so there are a lot of crude pixels and minimal sounds. I guess that also makes the gameplay retro, because it certainly isn't all that easy.There are so many things you have to take into consideration. Do you have enough spare tires, batteries and gas for your car, or enough food and medkits for your crew ? Are you prepared to trade stuff in order to get some of these things ? Do you even have stuff to trade ? If not, you have to scavenge for items. But is it safe from zombies or is the place packed ? And do you spend your money on buying upgrades for your car, or do you spend it on buying just the necessary ?There are a few boss fights, too, and quite a couple of random events, like, what are you going to do when a friend is being held hostage (shoot the guy in the face of course !) ? These random factors make this a great and fun game.The aiming, however (when you're scavenging or doing jobs), takes some getting used to. It becomes somewhat natural after a while, but doesn't feel quite right. I guess the developer chose this control scheme to keep the game more tense. If that's the case; they have succeeded. Congratulations developer !If you're still on the fence about buying this: I can highly recommended it.[Rating: 81/100]

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												If you have a nostalgia itch for the old Oregon Trail game, it's an okay way to kill an hour or two. That said...I didn't have a good experience. Some of the mini-games upon leaving settlements are fun (e.g. biker attack, etc.), and the scavenging is interesting for the first handful of times. After that, everything just felt pointless.Resources: While scavenging, you only ever find 3 of the 8 or so resources you need. It quickly became quite boring to always find the same 3 things over and over again. I ended up with uselessly huge stockpiles of these resources to the point that they became irrelevant, and spent days waiting for traders to come by and offer to trade for anything else. This may be better on harder difficulties, but it was my first time through, so "normal" seemed like the logical choice.Party: As far as I can tell, there's no point to keeping your party alive other than just for the sake of keeping them alive. This is easier said than done, not because it's actually hard to care for them, but because they randomly wander off, and there's nothing you can do about it. Maybe I just had bad luck, but by 2/3 of the way through the trip all but one of my party had died this way. Maybe there's something that happens at the end if you have more survivors, but I never made it there because...With just a few stops left, my party saw "something interesting" happening off the highway. I chose to invesitage, and the game locked up. Just a black screen with the music playing and a little decorative pattern at the top. Apparently this is a common problem.Other reviewers here seem to like it. I found it repetitive, and all the progress I made was too easily wiped out by completely random mechanics and technical problems, making the game more frustrating than fun.TL;DR: Repeatedly scavenged for the same 3 items in order to feed a party that wandered off and died anyway. Then the game crashed. There are better games available for $5. If you can get it for a buck or two on sale, it might be worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												The Organ Trail. Right away I’m brought back to the good ole elementary school days of needlessly shooting buffalo and overfishing because it was considered “educational.” This game is a zombie spoof of the ever so beloved pioneer traveling game. You get to name your crew, pick your items, and board up into your station wagon to hit up the west. There are mini-games of wrecking biking crews and shooting zombies. The shooting mechanics are a bit clunky, but when you practice you’ll get better at it. Use a mouse; using a Facebook’s machine’s mouse pad will leave your tired and frustrated. Cute music and sound effects, the pixelated graphics will grow on you. It’s a fun spin on the traditional game. It’s a good game to burn sometime on, and you’ll find yourself amused at your friends catching dysentery because we all know the only people who know of such a disorder are the people whose virtual bffs got it while playing the Oregon Trail.  So board up your “wagon” and get on your way. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Good nostalgia, solid oldschool gameplay, and a zombie game I didn't want to chuck out for building predictible gameplay on top of cliches - it kept me guessing juuuust enough to keep me interested. Probably a better way to get your Oregon Trail fix than actually trying to go back and play the verison this is based off of - it scales nicely and looks great even on my 2560x1440 resolution and the music/sound is retro inspired but won't make your ears bleed after a couple hours like some of the older games will. It's also got some cute perks and other modes like a little physics one where you mow zombies down in your station wagon and an endless mode. I probably won't go through and get all the unlocks and acheivements, but if you love it there's a lot here that tempts you for another few playthroughs.

												Amazing Game! 9.5/10Recommending everyone while it is on sale (2,50 EUR)Really good game about moving from the east coast to the west coast in the USA trying to reach Safe Haven. The mechanics of the game are really cool and managing your partys supplies is tons of fun. You can rename the people helping you (or messing stuff up) on the journey. It is a amazing pixel-art-ish game with tons of replayability. It is funny and entertaining at once because of all that random♥♥♥♥♥♥that happens (Trading your teammates; Bike gangs attacking you; Meeting messed up survivors). It took me 2h 40mins to complete the game on medium difficulty. I enjoyed it alot :)(As for the mobile android version, its good but the scavenging/zombie action/shooting is very annoying + frustrating even when playing on a 5 inch display because of the controls)

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												This is the best zombie survival game I've ever played. For as simple looking as it is, it's actually very thorough with a ton of content. It's hard to understand the first time you play it. But once you get used to how it all works, it can be very addicting. I like the click-pull-shoot idea (which is almost impossible without a mouse) for the 2d game, it might be difficult to do at first but it’s a whole different shooting system. I would recommend this game mostly for passing the time though, it is very fun, but not something you (or at least I) would actually put time aside to play. But all in all, this game is definitely worth 4.99. The best part is writing and finding you own gravestone when you die, or when you visit a grave.Get it. If you’ve ever played low graphic games and liked them, you’ll like this.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Good nostalgia, solid oldschool gameplay, and a zombie game I didn't want to chuck out for building predictible gameplay on top of cliches - it kept me guessing juuuust enough to keep me interested. Probably a better way to get your Oregon Trail fix than actually trying to go back and play the verison this is based off of - it scales nicely and looks great even on my 2560x1440 resolution and the music/sound is retro inspired but won't make your ears bleed after a couple hours like some of the older games will. It's also got some cute perks and other modes like a little physics one where you mow zombies down in your station wagon and an endless mode. I probably won't go through and get all the unlocks and acheivements, but if you love it there's a lot here that tempts you for another few playthroughs.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												I really enjoyed my time with Organ Trail: Director's Cut. It's like Oregon Trail (I have fond memories of playing this in computer class when I was in grade school in the early to mid '90s), and the game even has a very retro feel. Instead of the new frontier theme of Oregon Trail you'll be treated to a dark and somber Zombie theme... although the game is littered with some light humor. It'll take some wits, skill, and luck to get across the US. Overall I thought the game was a lot of fun, and it's a game I know I'll come back to every so often. I even have it on my tablet and played through it (it takes roughly 2 1/2 hrs to clear... if you can make it) in the hospital while I was waiting for my daughter to arrive. I think a lot of people would like Organ Trail, and I especially recommend it to the people that have fond memories of playing the original Oregon Trail.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												I've been playing this before it got released on Steam. Well worth the $5 bucks. Gameplay is decent but challenging. Aiming and shooting don't come easy but if you were a survivor in a zombie apocalypse and you never fired a gun shooting wouldn't come easy to you too. Achievements add a decent amount of replayability. There's also a few different game modes to challenge you and a couple of mini-games that you discover along your journey. Highly recommended if you're a fan of Oregon Trail or if you're just a fan of zombies... this game is like a re-imagined version but with a zombie twist. I've had lots of fun with this.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game is... uhm, what?  That's a pretty good description, yeah.It's really just a rehash of that old mac Oregon trail, from the graphics to the sounds to the strange difficulty.  However, Organ Trail is much easier.The trouble is that there really isn't much game here.  It's a lot of sitting and making decisions, which you know, worked for a sort of educational game but not so much this.  It's just a parody, really.  Good for one run, maybe two, but that's about it.I'm not really knocking it, just, yeah.  Play it through once and you're done.  At most?  Probably three hours.I recommend it, I guess.  It's not bad.  Bit boring sometimes and I never could play it for long durations, but it's not exactly a long game, either.  I enjoyed some of the parody elements but a lot were, I don't know, eh?It has some good things going on though, so maybe check it out.  It's not expensive.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												At first it might seem only a parody of "Oregon Trail", that's only made to parodise a well-known game. But when you start to REALLY get in to it, you'll understand that this game has a interesting strory: it is about you and your group of friends trying to survive the oh-so-suden zombie apocalypse, making though choices (selling/buying neccessary supplies, putting down infected party members), and most importantly making it to "Safehaven", a place that is rumored to be the safest place in America.Every time you start a new story, you'll be able to pick 5 names for your group of survivors, the game spawns random events, that make you lose precious supplies. It suddenly starts minigames that make you evade a group of bikers/a horde of reindeers. Every time you start a new playthrough, it will be like playing a brand new game.If you like games about rainbows, this game is not for you. If you like games about unicorns, this game is not for you.If you want to put your zombie survival skills to good use in a very unique way, then this game is for you.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												A nostalgic walk back to a simpler time in gaming, with a zombified twist.  The pixel-art designs of each stop along the journey has sly references to other games and movies related to the genre.  My eyes weretreated to creative details the longer I stared at each of these playfully macabre settings.  The trip across the States was filled with engaging events and opportunities to trade, fight zombies, and upgrade my car and combat skills.For +1 to your fun factor, name the people who join you on the journey after folks you know in real life.  I lost my sister-in-law early on, which I'm sure my brother held as a grudge against me the rest of the trip.  Whether or not you played the quintessential Oregon Trail growing up, this game deserves your attention with its grim-spirited, tongue-in-cheek, yet challenging, and full-of-replay-value package.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												For the price I paid for it, I'm not too upset about buying this game ... but, even at that price, this game is basically a one-shot joke that is given away in the title. If you're both a massive zombie fan and are nostalgic for the original Oregon Trail then maybe you would get slightly more enjoyment out of it, but I never played the Oregon Trail (although similar games from the same period, e.g. Granny's Garden if anyone remembers that...), and really there is only about 10-20 minutes of entertainment here.On the plus side: the execution as far as they were aiming for is solid, the retro graphics style is done very well, and it's nice to hear a few bleeps and bloops. But the minigames get boring incredibly quickly, could've done with a few more of them to keep things varied, and there just isn't the depth to make this interesting to play. I got very close to winning on my first game but for the amount of content here it takes absolutely ages to get there and I wasn't compelled to try again.However like I said, for a few quid you can't really go wrong, if you're intrigued by this game then you might as well go for it!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												An interesting approach to the over-done "zombie apocalypse" themed doomsday games, Organ Trail combines pixelated graphics with poor controls to deliver a less than satisfying adventure. Had the controls been easier to get used to, the game might have had a chance at playability solely for the sake of it, but sadly, the catapult style of aiming is not my thing and since there is no way to change it, I quit after 10 minutes or so.Sadly, the game appears to hae nothing new to add storywise either: end of the zorld through zombies, friends in a party trying to survive, trying to find a safe place... Sound familiar? Combined with the poor graphics, and horrible gameplay controls, I'd say you are better off avoiding this game completely.
