number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												Nostalgia is a weakness of mine. I have 8 different game consoles going back to the SEGA Master System, and I still play them all. Any game that can offer a memorable experience with a big dose of familiarity is likely to score points with me. Organ Trail delivers.My love of zombie lore is well known, so a game that promises cannibalistic carnage is already on the wishlist. But the real reason I'm recommending this little gem is for the mental rush it gives me. I feel like I'm back in 2nd grade computer class, and Miss Eissens said we could stop the typing and play. I spent many frustrating and rewarding hours shooting buffalo and fording rivers, only for Mary to get dysentery and die horribly. The original Oregon Trail is one of those games that everyone has played, whether they're a gamer or not. Organ Trail is a faithful homage and a ridiculous zombie apocalypse yarn as well. The graphics are simple, 16-color pixels, the controls are hair-pullingly difficult to master, and even on the lowest difficulty setting, you are not reaching Safe Haven without taking a few hits. The random events include blizzards, sandstorms, and bandits. You have to keep your party healthy, and you have to make sure your station wagon doesn't break down. You'll also have to ford hordes of zombies, engage in shoot-outs with gangs, and buy and sell food, ammo, scrap, fuel, car parts, and medkits. There are loads of references to other zombie games and films, including Left 4 Dead, Zombieland, Evil Dead, and many, many more. The game has a juvenile sense of humor and a pleasing measure of self-awareness; it's possible to encounter a stranger in town who simply says "these controls suck!"There are nearly 30 achievements and over 300 unique tombstones to find (including... YOUR OWN!), encouraging replayability. Endless mode and Clements Quest are also welcome additions to the formula, and there's in-game "Skulls" to shoot for while playing. Heh. Skulls. Shoot. I'm funny.Organ Trail is not going to please everyone. This game is not for the hardcore FPS player or someone who wants an in-depth story and simple controls. This game is for people who remember the ecstacy and the agony of playing Oregon Trail back in the day and thinking "yeah, it's fun, but it could use more zombies."

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												An interesting, parodical take on the notorious and educational Oregon Trail games. However, instead of a covered wagon of pioneers trekking from Missouri to Oregon across the 19th-century American Midwest, replace all that with a station wagon of survivors trekking from Washington, D.C. to California across post-apocalyptic America. From the gameplay to the graphics, everything in Organ Trail: Director's Cut pays homage to the classic Oregon Trail for the Apple II, but it adds its own interesting twists for a unique experience. Multiple difficulty levels, game modes, unlockables, achievements, and other various extras give it a good amount of replayability. The controls are a little wonky and take some time to get used to, but the game is solid otherwise. Amidst a sea of other zombie games, Organ Trail: Director's Cut manages to be unique by creatively merging multiple ideas, both modern and classic, to create a rewarding gameplay experience.

However it gets a bit carried away with the micro transactions, and having to wait around a lot.Also I just encountered a bug the moment I submitted this review, so now my experience is soured because I'm stuck in some small glitch that I have no idea how to fix, I'm stuck in front of a hord in the rain, but I can't stop, wait, or move, so I can only assume the creators didn't intend to make their game unplayable and it has to be a bug. It's a small one that not many people have encountered, so I'll give it a pass for now, since they could patch it and otherwise this is a fun game.It really feels like a tablet game after you play it a while, and it is coming out for tablet devices so that makes sense. I think it's fun, but I'm glad I didn't pay full price, it's more of a game you want to play to pass some time, waiting at the band or waiting for your meal at a resturant if you're with people you don't want to talk to.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!Interface/Menu/SettingsThe graphics are Pixelated.The music is very old schoolish but repetive.The game has Local Co-op, but only available on Events.There is a Volume slider that affects Music or Sound. Even Click! (Bullet)You can play this with a Controller (because of 2-player mode)There is a Campaign and Endless Mode.There is an Auto-save Version, For each hour/move that you are doing.There is a Difficulty Settings. About the gameYou can Name your main character and all Party members.There is a Day and night cyclus, which will affect the game difficulty. As in too dangerous or safe.There are Events in the game, Negative, Positive and neutrals ones.There are "random" Boss Events.You play with a pixelated character in events, That has to shoot zombies, Bandits and getting Resources.You have Party members that may get sick/infected/die or cause for trouble.There are Cities, Where you can buy stuff, like Car or main character upgrades, Sell stuff, or even trade stuff. They also have Jobs which you may could do to get an extra of something! Other thingsThere is a Serious game-breaking bug going on which put you in a huge advantage and good state.Once you have completed an event, like "Scavenge", They will show you how much resources you have collected. When that screen pops-up and u have like 100 Food and 20 Scrap from that event.Press Shift-tab and then click on "return to game" You will get the popup screen again, Do Shift-tab again and then click on return to game. And once again you will get the same popup screen again.(This works on fullscreen and window mode and you need to active steam overlay.)You are able to take a wrong turn.... even if u are just driving on 1 straight road.Try to do Drive or Scavenge when the Horde is quiet. If you are driving or doing scavenge in Night time(Which will increase the zombie difficulty by alot) There is a higher chance for a negative event.Otherwise just Rest, Repair or Trade.Bandit Missions are relative easy, Even on suicide. It is all about Timing. So do not be afraid to give this a try.Let's Try Video:

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Organ Trail...where to begin? If it isn't the zombies killing you, which it rarely is, it's the idiotic actions played out by your fellow survivors. In my whole life, I've never broken a bone but each person in your group may break several within a few weeks. I have played a fair amount of this game and I can honestly say that it was worth what I paid for it. The unfortunate reality of a post-zombie outbreak is very apparent throughout the game. I guess once a zombie outbreak occurs everyone forgets how to drive (since you bust your car on almost every turn), how to just be mindful of your possessions (since you break♥♥♥♥♥♥all the time), and herds of deer and very poorly managed biker gangs run rampant across the whole country. If it is on sale, which it is a lot, I wouldn't pass it up. And for a low price of $5 when it isn't on sale, why wait?

												This games fantastic and cheap, I usually write bigs reviews but i'll keep this one short.Its probably one of my favourites, if i had a top 50 it would certainly be in there, i believe its based on a game called Oregon trail for the Atari 2600 as well, it looks aged and feels aged but the gameplay is just so well done, you've to basically travel from one side of the USA to the other, lots can go wrong and lots can happen while traveling, theres a nice amount of randomly generated content to keep this fresh and the gameplay just feels fantastic.Its rather hard to talk about all the great things in this game without showing it to you, this game doesn't look like anything special at all, infact i only picked it up on sale because it was literally only about £2 and its been the best £2 i've ever spent, you won't get hundreds of hours out of it but you'll have an experience you'll remember strong, it feels good to play this game and even better to complete it, if i were to pick one indie game to give out to everyone for free for them to play and experience it would probably be this one, it deserves a sequel!

												I seem to recommend a lot of titles with zombies in 'em, and this is gonna be another one. Take the classic edutainment title The Oregon Trail and replace the setting of 19th century emigrants with the zombie apocalypse and you've got this game. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I had to look twice to see if this was a retro classic that had been re-released or ported to the steam store. But it turns out it's not, and is indeed an original/fresh game.The graphics are authentic of what you would expect from a game during the days of the sega master system (and before). Do not be put down by the graphics however, as the gameplay is certainly there. I haven't had so much fun with a pixel based sprite game in at least a decade. There are lots of elements to the game that give you a rush of nostalgia, be it the music, the menu systems, or the animations, it certainly brought back memories of some titles on the sega mega drive; for me.The various gameplay mechanics also work well, even though they are fairly simple. It's also quite fun to discover an old gravestone on the road-side (with a personal message that you wrote) on the next play through.I also have to say that the soundtrack is brilliant. Most games that i enjoy for years to come have succeeded on the basis of the music and the gameplay alone, i think Organ Trail might be one of them.I ended up with this game after the purchase of a recent humble-bundle, but having played a few hours through Organ Trail, i think it's somethin gi would've paid full price for on it's own. 10/10 from me. Lots of fun, and importantly; lots of replayability.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												We all loved Oregon Trail growing up. We would spend hours, trying to make it across the new world. Hunting for food, trading for bullets and wagon parts and struggling to keep your family alive, challenged by starvation and illness! Well guess what, If you love Zombies and Oregon trail, this is the game for you! I've already played many stories, seen many things, and have survived many times, but lost a few. Travel to the safehouse across the zombie-ridden United States, scavenging for food, scrap, and money. Trade with locals to get new parts for your station wagon, or more bullets. Run from stampeding zombie deer and fight off bandit attacks! You know those rivers you forded in Oregon Trail? Well now you ford your way through zombie hordes! Still not enough for you? Why don't you go ahead and invite a celebrety to ride in your station wagon with you? You might just get a surprise!

												I'm not sure exactly what I thought this game would be like, but that doesn't matter.What matters is, that I got positively surprised by this game.Yes, it's not a very long campaign, but who cares?The replayability in this game is high, since it's completely random.Well, of course it isn't COMPLETELY random, but the events are random.I bought this a day or two ago, and I've already gotten 3 hours in it. ''Yeah, so what? That's not very much.'' I know it might not be much, but it just seem so fresh to me, and saying that I already got 3 hours in it isn't very smart of me, considering I have, by no means, been playing it non stop.I'm no expert in games like these, but it feels like a lot of content for the price tag.I'm gonna give it a 9 / 10 , because it does what it sets out to do very well.My main problem with it is just the fact that the hitboxes when scavenging are a bit messed up. The hitboxes I'm talking about is the players. Sometimes you will feel cheated, or feel that it isn't fair, that the zombie could hit you. Why would you feel like that? Because it isn't fair, the player's hitbox is a bit too large, but it's easy to look past when the rest of the game is so addictive.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Organ Trail is an obvious parody of the old-school game 'Oregon Trail', a game I must admit I've never played, despite hearing so much about it.  I do know what makes a good game, though, and this is brilliant.The aim of the game is simple; survive in a post-apocalyptic zombie-led world as you and four companions make it across the United States to the last remaining human stronghold.  Riding in a clapped-out station wagon, you'll need to gather what meagre supplies you can, keeping a close eye on your food, fuel, ammo and equipment for your vehicle, while riding from safe zone to safe zone.At each safe zone, you'll be able to rest, repair and trade, along with taking part in optional scavenger missions or jobs that put you at greater risk.  The road between each zone is littered with random encounters, from conversation set pieces to shoot-outs, from graverobbing to surviving stampedes of undead animals.What makes this game brilliant is it is the perfect balance of risk versus reward.  Low on food? You could scavenge the surroundings while multiple zombies approach, but if they catch you, it could be all for naught.  Can your station wagon survive until the next zone, or should you stop in no-mans land and attempt to repair it? How long should you keep a valuable companion alive that has been bitten by the undead?  Should you blast through that zombie horde, or wait for it to disperse while your supplies dwindle?  And should you push your vehicle faster, to save on food and get to Safe Haven? Or would you go at a more leisurely pace, and risk running low on supplies?It's important to note that this game is a fun diversion, a full playthrough taking no more than a few hours.  The mini-games are varied but very basic, as are the graphics - don't get this expecting anything more than crudely drawn Amstrad style animations.  The companions that accompany you are also nothing more than the name you give them.  It's best, then, to go into this game with a wild imagination, rather than a massive expectation of an epic zombie survival thriller.Finally, a shout-out must go to the gorgeous music, which is capable of inspiring terror and elation in equal measure.  It perfectly encapsulates the beautiful-yet-irrevocably scarred landscape that you must cross to reach your goal.For the price, definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												As a child I played the Oregon Trail on those, now ancient, Apple II computers while in the computer lab of my elementary school. back then the thing to do was die of measles, snakebite, dysentery, typhoid, cholera, or exhaustion while moving along the historic Oregon Trail. I remember we had some good times trying to make that trip. My favorite thing to do in this game was to go hunting. It was so easy to point and click at the animal you wished to kill.In Organ Trail: Director's Cut hunting is not nearly as easy. You have to hold down the mouse button and pull back in the equal but opposite direction to the zombie you want to kill. Over complicated for no reason. This is my only complaint about this game though.I enjoy that this game brings back all of the old memories of my childhood while simultaneously including a modern spin on a post apocalyptic zombie outbreak. Each difficultly level is challenging but not so challenging that it is super frustrating. This is a great game that everyone can play comfortably without quitting in a thunderous rage.I strongly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2013
												Organ Trail is a game that is pretty much what you're expecting: Oregon Trail with zombies in it. The game takes care to explore the wonderful word of '80s graphics and user interfaces, but doesn't do the dumb mistake of going all-in on nostalgia in many aspects, opting for difficulty settings and WASD control methods. The couple of things it keeps from Oregon Trail are the basic structure of the game as well as the savage Murphy's Law ♥♥♥♥ery permeating the gameplay. And also it has zombies in it, but ♥♥♥♥ you, it's a nice reimagining.

												Nostalgia wrapped in a deadly but all too familiar blanket. Organ Trail will bring back those memories of playing Oregon Trail games on a school computer in elementary school, but it's got it's own thing going on here. Very fun. Name your friends after your real friends and watch them die horribly or put them down when they start to turn. A game of hard choices and satisfying conclusions. Your choices really do matter. Play with the DLC for even more fun, like dying of radiation poisoning. Fully recommend this blast from the past.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												I myself have never been a fan of zombie games.  Other than tell tales walking dead, I have not found myself very interested in most zombie games. I hated left4dead, and thought dead island was incredibly medicore. But this game is AMAZING. despite using an "atari" graphical style, and not exactually riviting in terms of music or dialouge ect, I found myself more emotionally attached to my own pixelated characters. Than any triple A zombie game out there.  As you progress, your resources get lower and lower, and things get tougher. The game gave me an odd sense of doom, but hope at the same time. And that hope is what kept me playing. To make it through.  I usually for the most part do not like indie games.  But with it's cheap price, and great replay value, I highly highly reccomended this.  I would hope for a sequel. But maybe it's better off being a stand alone game.  Whoever made this game, I commend you for the great amount of effort put into this simplistic but at the same time, complicated game.The game is primarly about resource managment, and going across the USA, in hopes of getting to your final destination, "safe haven" you have to survive zombies, bandits, and get supplies, fix your car, ect, it's based off one of my favorite PC game series, "The Oregon Trail" I might even argue that this game is a tad bit better than the original Oregon Trail games. I'd highly reccomended it.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												It's a good game, but flawed. The writing, theory, and graphics are all where they need to be and what you should expect from a zombie game based on Organ Trail, funny and dark. The biggest issue for me is the actual gameplay. Aiming is practically some sort of witchcraft, there's no way you complete some jobs, at least I couldn't. The other issue is the dullness of the AI. I beat the game and shot maybe 12 zombies, if you have decent left hand skills you will be fine, because even Pac Man had more challenging AI. So why am I recommend it? Because the game works, is fun and enjoyable, gunpaly aside, and at least someone is trying to freshen up the zombie safe heaven escape story line.

YouTube™ Video: SteamPunk Episode 9: Organ Trail, Director's Cut 

			Views: 95		

			SteamPunk Bob just couldn't get enough zombies from one retro graphics zombie sim, noooo, he had to get TWO!		

It's a passable Oregon Trail homage, with a heavy emphasis on gunplay. The problem is... the aiming controls are just plain AWFUL. In a game where nearly every problem is solved by shooting zombies or thieves, you NEED to be able to snap and aim quickly, and this cannot be done with this control scheme.

Posted: January 7, 2016
												My 4-ish hours are actually solely from farming cards. I won this game at a giveaway and I only participated on that because the store page reads "full controller support". I never had a problem with controller support not working in games when the store page says it's present (even if it's just partial), but it's practically non-existent for Organ Trail. Developers seem to have either abandoned the game or just can't be bothered to give information reagarding their mistake, as I'm not the only one (certainly not the first either) to complain about the lack of controller support when the devs went all the way to say it's fully supported. Thumbs down for the false information and absent developers who, despite the game's success (or exactly bc of it), don't even care to fix the information on the store page.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Organ Trail is a parody of the classic Oragan trail, but is this a parody you want to try ? In Organ Trail you and your group are trying to get to Safe haven among a zombie apocalypse. So how is this game ? Its pretty great game apart from the difficulty. In the game youre going to point A to B. Its really hard to explain so ill try to summerize. there many thing you do so here we go nuber 1 you drive from city to city in those citys you trade for supplies to help you survive. Number 2 you can scavenge and collect supplies so you dont have to pay for them and there are many jobs rainging from getting something somoene lost to killing bandits. This game has much to do about strategy and rationing youre supplies which may become difficult when the game wants to cheat with ya. Overall this game is a good expierience if you want to feel like you are in a zombie apocalypse with rationg supplies and trying to stay alive also it adds a second campaing for free which is awesome so the final score im giving this game is an 8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												An excellent satire of the pioneering (pun intended) educational series, Oregon Trail.Falls very flat if you either aren't familiar with the original games or aren't remotely interested in satire of educational games--  on the other hand, if you can recall (fondly) what sort of things you did Oregon Trail, you'll be able to understand and appreciate where much of the humor in this game comes from, and enjoy it for what it is.If you're part of the target audience, you'll probably already have an inkling that you might like this game.  To everyone else, I can't recommend it.  (Though it's not like it'll put a big dent in your wallet anyway, especially when it's on sale.)

Really enjoyable game if you like taking rough decisions and gambling for your survival and you are able to overlook the graphics and the sounds (of course if you are a retro fan like myself, you will love them). Even if randomness has a great part, skill is also needed and not only "decision-skill" (which implies some mathematician skill as well, to measure your chances good) or gambler skill (luck) but also aiming skill. Another nice part is the customization part. But my favorite part, with which maybe I should have started is: THIS IS ONE OF THE BEST TRADING  SIMULATORS DURING A ZOMBIE APOCALYPSE...EVER!

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												"Organ Trail is a retro zombie survival game. Travel westward in a station wagon with 4 of your friends, scavenging for supplies and fending off the undead; Faithfully recreated it as if it were on the Apple 2. Packed full of zombie mechanics, themes and references; this is a must have for any zombie survival fans."Truer words cannot be spoken. If you have a touch of nostalgia or want to jump in your time machine and go back to the time when floppy disks ruled the earth, then this game is for you. From the midi music to the graphics, the game is retro through and through.Total time it took me to complete it was set at around 3 hours, and by the first 30 minutes you already know the entire game mechanics and how to beat them.Like with any dubstep song however, you gotta wait for the drop:I would not recommend buying it unless you are feeling nostalgically retro, $5 is a bit steep seeming as you can get a host of golden oldies off of websites such as Abandonia for free and the only reason I came across this game was because it was included in one of the Humble Bundles.I say that just like zombies, the modern-retro era is dead and this game serves to merely show us what horrors lurked in the past in the form of 8 bit graphics and midi scores that leave your ears bleeding. The past was great but we have come a long way from it - no point in trying to resurrect it in the hope that it bites a gamer and sets off a retro gaming contagion.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Organ Trail is a very fun game. And it's very comfy. But honestly, you're better off not buying this. The full game is riddled with bugs that'll make it freeze. I have never had that problem in the the flash game version. If you are seriously considering getting this, play the flash game first. If you still like that, consider if you're willing to wade through a heap of bull in the (pretty high) chance it locks up when you beat the game. This isn't even a rare occurence, this is a well known, reported, practically game breaking bug that has not been fixed in apparently months of it being known. And what does this version add over the flash game? Harder difficulties, but they're still pretty easy; Scavenging is absolutely overpowered even with the more difficult shooting controls. Extra content as far as picking what sprite your character uses, special buyable power ups, and unlockable starting vehicles. Plus, there's a minigame that's very similar to Spongebob's Boat-O-Cross. Not really a huge step up; the only major points are the new job system and being able to pick alternate routes at certain spots on the map. All in all, if you want to play, you should really just stick with the flash game unles you get this version cheap. Even so, be prepared to deal with lock ups.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												This is a zombiefied version of the 1980's Oregon Trail game, popular with schoolchildren in the 1980's. Apart from a chuckle and some nostalgia for Americans, this game offers very dated and primitive gameplay that could be easily accomplished in a web browser using Flash.The PC version of this game is simplistic pixel graphics that makes the NES look good (which, I suppose, is an homage to the 1980's game). Clearly if it's doing something your smartphone could do, or could be done in a browser, nostalgia aside, it's not worth spending any money on as it's not offering a genuine PC gaming experience.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2013
												A zombie-themed spoof of the classic, Organ Trail is a terrificly addictive survival strategy game with a dash of action for good measure. This game puts you in a charge of a group of 4 other survivors of a zombie apocalypse, the goal being to get yourself and your comrades from Washington, D.C. to a safe zone on the West Coast. You'll encounter bandits, zombie hordes, bike gangs, and other perils along the way. There's multiple skill levels, and every game is random, making sure that you never know what will happen on your dangerous journey!

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Good money well spent.  I had to change my review slightly after playing it more.  But...Organ Trail can still be a nice divergion.  I feel like the choices you make while on the road don't quite make a big deal in the long run.  The differences here between this and Oregon Trail is that Oregon trail gives you different paths to take with positives and negatives associated with them plus a mini game to complete the task.  Organ Trail has this too (if you buy the dlc) but the differences are very minute and you don't get to really experience doing the different path.  Your car just keeps milling about on the road without any input from you.  Most of the time I just skip all the messages that pop up because it's all RNG.  You have no input in whether you lose a bunch of ammo or food.  The game just does everything for you while yoiu auto drive.The different paths you take just means a faster route plus more hazards, like radiation sickness.  The towns are all the same. Some have trainers and others, upgrades for your car.  Thats really the only BIG difference in choosing a different path.  Scavenging gets old REAL fast.  If you buy the dlc, you can fight off humans as well as the undead.  All in all, it's a decent waste of time.  You just wont be coming back to it over and over.  It's more of a 1-2 hr time waster when you're really bored.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												So, I didn't really have fun with the game as much I thought I would. I love zombies and I love surving and managment, but the game just got dull after a while. It was the same formula over and over, get to a town, scavenge, take jobs, bob and weave to the right to get what the guy who hred you wanted, fix your car, rest trade, then leave. This happened again and again, witha few variations on the road such as getting attacked by radiers on bikes. But soon those got dull as they were repeated again and again, and I had figured out and beat them before with ease minus a few hickups. Only very interesting thing that happened was when the friends I put in game would mess with componets with a car, which I could completly see them doing, and y most clumsy friend in real life consitently kept on breaking bones, which I thought was pretty funny. Oh and a random event when one of my friends got captured by a bandit and I missed the shot to save her so she got her head blown off. That and the soundtrack and some of the art in game were the only fun moments, as everything else became a dull repeat. Maybe it was just not for me.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												This game is awful.finding a car battery damages your party.finding food damages your party.stopping for any reason damages your party. (And you can't control when you stop.)The only actual gameplay is a handful of boring minigames which are very similar and the reward for completing them seems to have nothing to do with the "Missions" difficulty.  The rest of the game is either driving which rarely gives you a choice, and, I repeat, EVERY SINGLE EVENT, REGARDLESS OF OUTCOME, DAMAGES YOUR PARTY. this is the order of gameplay:1. drive2. damage party and car.3. car breaks down, takes tons of time, supplies, and PARTY HEALTH to fix it. (I'm not even kidding. The car broke down 5 times in one hour of gameplay.)4. reach town5. do a maximum of 2 missions.6. repeat.There are only 3 different weapons. And only 3 different enemies. And all party members are interchangable, (they have no unique skills.) except yourself, who can gain skills in towns, only you can only have 3, they have a very small effect, and you'll never be able to afford one. I requested a refund an hour after i got the game.

number of helpful: 8 of 24 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												If you're looking for a game where your energy is directed towards the task of making touchscreen controls work with a mouse with a splash of Apple II nostalgia thrown in, go for it. I paid $1.99 for this game and I want my money back.The shooting controls are meant for a tablet, and the developer seems to be more interested in making excuses for being too lazy to adapt the game to PC controls than actually doing work to fix it. Sure, I could waste time practicing such a stupid mechanic, but I don't consider it fun. Maybe the rest of the game is fun, but I don't feel like finding out. The game isn't witty enough or interesting enough to grab me and get me to fight past such a glaring flaw.The excuse used for not having keyboard controls for shooting is that with a keyboard you can only aim in 8 directions. If they honestly believe that, they are terrible programmers. Even if that were true, it would be a thousand times better than what exists currently.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												Organ Trail is a beutiful game which allows you to take care of your own fellow survivers. The game mainly takes place in a station wagon in a zombie epidemic. You have yourself and a few other party members to take care of as random events take place in the game. There are also checkpoints at every so distance where your party can relax and look at the local market to see what they have for sale, fix and heal a few things/people or you can look and trade items with others. But if you don't feel like relaxing there are quests you can do for extra items. The game can be buetiful in a 8-bit way, but the game isn't very grabbing. It is a type of game where you would play every so often, just because you want to, theres no real story or campaign.The game is stunning overall, but isnt very grabbing for your attention.                                                                               5.8/10

Posted: September 29, 2013
												A very interesting take on the old "Oregon Trail" game.  A zombie survival game using the same template.  You need ammo, food, fuel, medical bags, etc....  You also need to maintain your vehicle.  You start at one end of the United States and have to make your way to the West coast.  Within each town you can find jobs or people to barter with.  There is still money, so you can just buy what you need, but it is expensive.  There is a bonus game after you finish the story.  A pretty interesting little game.

												Don't get me wrong, I quite like this game. However, it is brought down by a few game breaking glitches, such as not responding to the mouse or keyboard in menus, and blue shapes appering randomly. The worst one (spoiler) is when I was fighting the octopus, the screen all of a sudden went black and said "You made it to Safe Haven. Click anywhere to Continue" I click millions of times and mashed every key on my keyboard yet nothing happened. Then, I paused and unpaused, and the octopus reappeared in the middle of the screen and so did  my character. I fought it for about 20 minutes, but it wouldn't die, and the car had no health bar. I just sat there shooting its tentacles till I gave up and let it kill me. It gave me instructions for a stage, then showed a close up version of my character, but I could do nothing but pause and unpause. I now see the instructions and close up every time I load that save file. The game is still enjoyable, and these glitches don't occur very frequently, but I am incerdibly disapointed that these glitches have not been taken care of.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												What do you get when you combine flesh-eating monstrosities with a journey to the West? Organ Trail is a clever mash of the classic Oregon Trail with a modern take on the currently popular zombie craze. You and a group of friends must venture across the country, trying to survive the hordes of undead- from former friendly neighbors, to the local wildlife! The gameplay is relatively simple, and easy to get the hang of. You must travel between different safezones on the way to the west coast, occasionally dealing with random events such as zombie hoardes, bikers with a bone to pick, and the appreciated event of your companions not keeping their clumsy hands off your medkits. At each safezone (cities and the like), you can barter and do small missions for other survivors, such as finding their belongings in a small field, taking on bandits and the like, for small rewards.The only difficult part of the game is the aiming feature. It takes a little getting used to, but before long, you'll be blasting the dead...dead again, and blowing your friend's brains out when it's their time to go with your eyes closed. Overall, the game is a very relaxing, retro fun filled ride that's easy for any to get into. If you like zombies, traveling, the occasional case of dysentery, and cappin' a round in your friend's faces, what more can you ask for?

												This game is great, saw it on one of my friend's lists and bought it just because of the ingenious pun name and the hilarious preview. It's got the same basis, it's funny as Hell, and it's surprsingly exciting to play.Improvements?  It'd be awesome if this was multiplayer.  Also certain things don't make sense when you're the last one alive in your party...for example, if you try to blast through a zombie horde on the way out of town it still shows two other people firing their shotguns from your station wagon.  And if you're out of ammo...you shouldn't be able to select this option at all, yet you still can.Note to the creators: the HIGHLANDER achievement should be worded as it was in the show and the movies--"There can be only one," not as you have it on Steam, "There can only be one."  And in the explanation of how to get that achievement, Safe Haven is incorrectly mentioned as Safe Heaven...

Posted: June 29, 2014
												What is my opinion on Organ Trail: Director's Cut? Well for starters this game is a major parody of Oregon Trail, as well as other zombie movies and games. But this parody acually is very fun, and it also has you thinking about how much resources you are using, making difficult choices, always putting you in situations that you never wish you could be in. The journey is quite long, mainly because you are traveling cross-country in nothig but a station wagon, which can also mean that you have a ton of stops along the way. Stopping your travels and seeing a random event that that occurs can go 50/50 : You could either find a large amount of fuel for the station wagon, or you could come across a bandit who will shoot your friend while holding them hostege. Having the largest role in this apocolypse as the group leader, it's YOUR job to manage all of the supplies, as well as scavenge, drive, make choices, and fixing the station wa- really you are the one who does all of the work. Can you make it to Oregon? Can you keep your fellow survivors alive? What will you do if you run out of gas? Who has time to bury the dead in a zombie outbreak? Well I can't answer all of the questions that you may ask, that's up to you to decide. So: should you buy this game? My answer is yes.

												8/10Sold one of my group members to cannibals for 50 fuel cans.I always wanted to play the original oregon trail, but never had a chance to, I picked this up during the summer sale and was really pleasantly surprised! Exceeded my expectations. Poor graphics (unless retro pixelated graphics are your thing) but they defintely fit this game. Lots of good humor, and scavenging is pretty fun, which is good cause you'll want to do it a lot. arcade style 'combat' with a unique aiming method so you dont just click on the zombies/bandits to kill them, pretty good  once you get used to it. gets a bit repetitive after a while, but the amount of random events is quite large, in one playthrough the only thing that happened more than once was a character sitting on food or ammunition, 'ruining' it. I played on normal, and it was pretty easy (although fun), but I would imagine it could be quite a challenge on higher difficulty.Great idea, well made, fairly replayable, I'd reccommend it as a great timekiller if you can get it at a reasonable price (not sure what it normally sells for)

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I... really can't recommend this game, even for the low, low price for which I got it. I can be told that I'm "missing the point," but frankly... I really recommend just playing Oregon Trail. It's a similar experience, but slightly more enjoyable.The problem is that most of the time, this just felt unfair to me, in ways that a game should not be. Allow me to elaborate: I was playing on EASY, because I KNEW this game would be hard. And NONE of the minigames felt like a DECENT challenge. They were either so easy as to be pointless, or difficult to the point of frustration (like the shootouts with bandits who never miss and barely ever pop out of cover... Time Crisis felt more fair to me, and that's a game that's designed to EAT QUARTERS.) Every now and then, an interesting event would happen, but more often something would just be taken from me for no reason, and I had to accept it. No strategy, no rhyme or reason. I literally once picked up 3 cans of fuel as a raandom event and IMMEDIATELY had 4 stolen from me by bandits.And these bandits are the scourge of the gods. They are always teeming, always a threat, no matter how many you strike down, and are seemingly unaffected by zombies and hold no valuables, even bullets, that do not disintegrate once slain. They can steal fuel from the tank of a moving vehicle. They can kidnap a party member (again, from a moving vehicle) and hold him at gunpoint to force a single shot rescue with no grace on the aim; you LITERALLY have to be PERFECT.The game just makes it feel like you have no control over... anything. And not in the realistic way. Shops and jobs rarely offer what you need, ammo and fuel are insanely overpriced, your party members are mentally deficient enough to break spare parts for the car on a regular basis... and unless you have an $80 perk, you can only find food, scrap, and (I believe, rarely) ammo while scavenging. And I was only ever able to learn the perk that allowed me to find medkits.In short... I found this game just frutrating and disappointing. Maybe if you're a ridiculously huge zombie fanatic, it'll be more fun. Otherwise, I think Oregon Trail is just better-designed, and all the little "jokes" and references can be read for just as much effect. The game has potential, but it just feels like it doesn't offer enough. Nothing bad that happened to me (okay, save one gunshot wound that I quickly patched with my dozens of medkits) seemed like it happened as a result of my input... that much lack of control, where you can (seemingly easily) lose through no fault of your own, just doesn't appeal to me.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												This is pure MS-DOS fun. Me being a fan of MS-DOS, I was really excited when I saw this game. I had to buy it instantly. Man, was I not disappointed. This game follows in the vain of "Oregon Trail". You are stuck in Washington D.C. during the apocalypse. You meet a local man and he helps you get to your friends. You have to kill him as he gets bit but then you get to name your friends and you are off to go across to the country. The whole point of the game is to get to the Safe Haven; which is on the West Coast. You must balance your food and oil usage; while also making sure you have enough food, medkits, and ammo to survive. But for this, you need money. You can earn money or supplies by doing missions and cities or other pit-stops. This game can be challenging. So challenging that I haven't been able to make it to the end yet. But, it is a great experience. You will have fun trying to balance your supplies and the certain events you can come across can be challenging. You can choose how to deal with these situations but make sure you choose correctly; there can be some bad consequences if you don't. If you are fan of MS-Dos games, Oregon Trail, zombies, or challenging games then this is a must buy.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												For those that never experienced old Apple 2 style games, most of this game's charm and humor will be lost on you.  But for those that sat in the computer lab, mindlessly clicking away, this game is a rare treat and a crystal ball looking back into your childhood.  Many take to adding in names of their friends, but for me, I always added Spiderman, Batman, etc.  And it's very telling when Bruce Wayne crumples up money and destroys it out of boredom.  Rich b***ard.  While some of the key controls, IE shooting are bass-akwards, it didn't stop me from enjoying other parts of the game.While there is a working form of this game online, it doesn't have half the features of this game.  Do yourself a favor.  Get the full version and support the devs.  They gotta eat too.Pros:+Nostalgic look back at the old Oregon Trail game you played in school+Interesting easter eggs located at nearly every checkpoint (From Final Fantasy, to Last of Us, to Shaun of the Dead, and more)+Randomized events give high replay+Interesting Achievements add another degree of difficulty (Can you make it without any money?  What about no trading? etc.)+Good soundtrack mixed with old-school sound effects+Endless mode makes it so you can unlock new starter modes!Cons:-God awful inverted gun controls with no settings to change to normal-Glitchy counter, making certain achievements a course in futility -Zombie 'Boss Fights' are more of an exercise in running away than fighting off the undead.-Clements isn't around longer.Read all this way?  You deserve a treat.  Don't bring your friends to a zom-pocolypse.  Bring Chuck Norris.  Seriously.  Bring him.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												If you've played Oregon Trail, then you know what you're getting with the original Organ Trail; a pure parody of Oregon Trail set in a zombie infested post-apocalypic wasteland. Its gameplay is similar, its ideas are similar, and it's a lot of fun, just like the original source material.Here's the thing though, Organ Trail: Director's Cut is everything the original Organ Trail is, and much much more. Rather than just a parody - and I agree fully with what the creators say they intended the game to be - it is a game that stands above and beyond its own source material as a game in its own right.It's fun, it's dark, it's darkly funny, and it's honestly quite creepy in several places. The soundtrack is incredible and Ben Crossbones' musical talent lends itself perfectly, creating a wonderous, lonesome, tense and tragic air to the whole game. Rolling into a settlement (or the remains of a city), buying supplies and fixing/upgrading your Station Wagon, or learning new combat skills, trading and scavenging and talking with strangers was great before, but with the soundtrack it turns it into both wonderous relief and soul-crushing despair as you realise these are the few survivors left, and you should take what levity you can on your perilous road to a CHANCE at salvation.Be warned however. Easy difficulty may not be as rewarding but it is fun. If you want the extra points bonuses, rack up the difficulty, but be prepared for ungodly amounts of pain, because the jump from Easy to Normal is IMMEDIATELY visible. You will suffer at the hands of the game for your greed, so be sure you're REALLY good at aiming for a start.Total recommendation, totally worth every penny in sale or not. Get it, play it, love it. Just uh... don't play it late at night before you go to bed. You may have interesting dreams. o_o;o_o;;;the horror.... /the Horrorrr..../

Posted: June 6, 2014
												Organ Trail is a remake/parody of the classic Oregon Trail educational game from the late 70’s.  The premise is simple…travel across the nation from point A to B, foraging for supplies to sustain your journey while surviving the zombie apocalypse.  The gameplay is very straight-forward.  Outside of being largely a resource management game, it is mostly point and click shooting with the occasional scenario where you are given a set of choices on how to proceed.  The graphics and sound are almost painfully retro, but it does stay very true to the original which is a plus in my book.  The Director’s Cut includes an endless mode with its own set of “achievements” in the form of skulls you can unlock by performing certain feats within the game.  Unlocking these skulls opens up new modes which greatly increases the replay value.I was surprised I ended up sinking as much time as I did into this game (admittedly, some parts of the game were pretty boring).  But if you were a fan of the original Oregon Trail, I think you might enjoy this title.  I would also like to add that yes, even in post-apocalyptic times, you can still die of dysentery.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												There's good and bad with this one, but I'm pretty happy with it. It's a really good re-imagining of Oregon Trail 1 (for those of us old enough to have played the hell out of that game back in elementary school), and it's got some nice updates to make it fun for an adult audience as well. Since it's aimed at adults with nostalgia value, it's also fairly difficult (at least compared to Oregon Trail).That being said, there are some downpoints. 1.) it's still fairy buggy -- right now my save seems to be stuck somewhere in the desert because the game stopped for an event that never came, so my care is just sitting there. 2.) shooting is very finicky, but once you get the hang of it (it takes awhile), it's not so bad.All in all, I'd definitely recommend it, especially if it goes on sale. Plus, you get the added bonus of naming your party members after friends and then pointing and laughing when they die of choler --- I mean, zombism.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												What do you get when you combine flesh-eating monstrosities with a journey to the West? Organ Trail is a clever mash of the classic Oregon Trail with a modern take on the currently popular zombie craze. You and a group of friends must venture across the country, trying to survive the hordes of undead- from former friendly neighbors, to the local wildlife! The gameplay is relatively simple, and easy to get the hang of. You must travel between different safezones on the way to the west coast, occasionally dealing with random events such as zombie hoardes, bikers with a bone to pick, and the appreciated event of your companions not keeping their clumsy hands off your medkits. At each safezone (cities and the like), you can barter and do small missions for other survivors, such as finding their belongings in a small field, taking on bandits and the like, for small rewards.The only difficult part of the game is the aiming feature. It takes a little getting used to, but before long, you'll be blasting the dead...dead again, and blowing your friend's brains out when it's their time to go with your eyes closed. Overall, the game is a very relaxing, retro fun filled ride that's easy for any to get into. If you like zombies, traveling, the occasional case of dysentery, and cappin' a round in your friend's faces, what more can you ask for?

Posted: November 8, 2015
												Remember when you would play Oregon Trail in school, but simply spend the entire period playing the hunting minigame? Imagine if they made a whole game out of that.On the surface, Organ Trail seems like an absolutely brilliant concept: Oregon Trail set as a zombie apocalypse simulator where you must manage supplies and health of your party as you travel west not in a covered wagon, but a station wagon.The visual style earns every bit of this game's charm. The blocky Commodore 64-era graphics and music are spot on, and the combat and scavenging minigames are enjoyable to play whenever they come up.But after sitting down and playing through it several times, I discovered the same problems I've had with the original Oregon Trail: It's just too easy! Even on the hardest difficulty, I got through without any of my party members dying. 


YouTube™ Video: Organ Trail - Suicide difficulty 

			Views: 456		

			All party members alive. Apparently this is supposed to be hard? I don't have any commentary for the first 38 minutes because I was capturing footage and wanted some pure audio to use.		

Maybe I've been spoiled by stuff like Binding of Isaac, Spelunky, Risk of Rain, or Super Amazing Wagon Adventure, but this game is just too easy to provide a challenge if you take it seriously at all.If you play through the game strategically and carefully budget your supplies and ammo, the game simply stops being fun and just becomes tedious. It's as much fun as doing a school assignment, but without the added bonus of going to Disneyland if you get straight A's.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												If you've played Oregon Trail, then you know what you're getting with the original Organ Trail; a pure parody of Oregon Trail set in a zombie infested post-apocalypic wasteland. Its gameplay is similar, its ideas are similar, and it's a lot of fun, just like the original source material.Here's the thing though, Organ Trail: Director's Cut is everything the original Organ Trail is, and much much more. Rather than just a parody - and I agree fully with what the creators say they intended the game to be - it is a game that stands above and beyond its own source material as a game in its own right.It's fun, it's dark, it's darkly funny, and it's honestly quite creepy in several places. The soundtrack is incredible and Ben Crossbones' musical talent lends itself perfectly, creating a wonderous, lonesome, tense and tragic air to the whole game. Rolling into a settlement (or the remains of a city), buying supplies and fixing/upgrading your Station Wagon, or learning new combat skills, trading and scavenging and talking with strangers was great before, but with the soundtrack it turns it into both wonderous relief and soul-crushing despair as you realise these are the few survivors left, and you should take what levity you can on your perilous road to a CHANCE at salvation.Be warned however. Easy difficulty may not be as rewarding but it is fun. If you want the extra points bonuses, rack up the difficulty, but be prepared for ungodly amounts of pain, because the jump from Easy to Normal is IMMEDIATELY visible. You will suffer at the hands of the game for your greed, so be sure you're REALLY good at aiming for a start.Total recommendation, totally worth every penny in sale or not. Get it, play it, love it. Just uh... don't play it late at night before you go to bed. You may have interesting dreams. o_o;o_o;;;the horror.... /the Horrorrr..../

Posted: July 6, 2014
												Despite very dated graphics there is something charming about this game. The story, accidents on the way, pretty much all the things you could possibly encounter during your postapocalyptic east to west trip. There is a micromanaging part which I especially like about this game. It's about being smart when it comes to planning, to avoid being stranded or pushed against the wall. You can also name your companions after your friends or family and go for hardest level to enhance the mood. Will you sacrifice your beloved one if he's turning into a zombie? Will you swap your buddy for 10 gallons of gas and cart of food? And there's this special kind of "8-bit atmosphere" when it's middle of the night and you sit in glow of your monitor ekhm.. TV with the sound of crickets and digital bleeps :)

Posted: June 28, 2014
												For those of us who played Oregon Trail on an old IBM growing up, this game is perfect.  We grew up, and these guys helped the Oregon Trail "Style" of game to grow with us.  You could easily call this a OT Clone, but it's a bit more than that.  The gameplay/graphics are sentimental, but the content is rich and brings us an 8bit horror survival game.  It brings us a new story, and a new sense of urgency that it's forefather didn't.  Best of all, we get to trade in our covered wagon for a station wagon.  I would say that this is a great casual game, but I've not been able to play it casual.  Each time I load up, I have to play it start to finish. I might only have a few hours on (not sure how many), but this is definitely a great one when you just don't know what you want to play.  The only negative thing I could say negatively about this game is the irritating click, pull, aim method of shooting.  Of course, you could say this is the one thing that truly adds difficulty to the game.

												8/10Sold one of my group members to cannibals for 50 fuel cans.I always wanted to play the original oregon trail, but never had a chance to, I picked this up during the summer sale and was really pleasantly surprised! Exceeded my expectations. Poor graphics (unless retro pixelated graphics are your thing) but they defintely fit this game. Lots of good humor, and scavenging is pretty fun, which is good cause you'll want to do it a lot. arcade style 'combat' with a unique aiming method so you dont just click on the zombies/bandits to kill them, pretty good  once you get used to it. gets a bit repetitive after a while, but the amount of random events is quite large, in one playthrough the only thing that happened more than once was a character sitting on food or ammunition, 'ruining' it. I played on normal, and it was pretty easy (although fun), but I would imagine it could be quite a challenge on higher difficulty.Great idea, well made, fairly replayable, I'd reccommend it as a great timekiller if you can get it at a reasonable price (not sure what it normally sells for)

Posted: July 15, 2013
												When I first saw the title, I immediately thought it was Oregon Trail only to find out it was a twisted variation of that original title. I have to say playing Organ Trail brings back a lot of fun memories of playing the original Oregon Trail on the Apple IIe some 30+ years ago. Organ Trail is a pretty cheesy rip off, but the developers did a great job in emulating an old school classic.They even threw in a few L4D references like a picture of the entrance to No Mercy hospital with Francis as a zombie, the L4D2 hand at grave sites, and an unforgettable finale providing L4D2 scavenge style gas can filling in 2D goodness. For what it is, Organ Trail is an enjoyable little adventure down memory lane.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												(I have more playtime on an abandoned account.) I've taken a liking to Organ Trail's concept since I played the lesser version on Adobe Flash in my browser. I'm too young to have ever played Oregon Trail, which Organ Trail is based on. Others can tell you the pros and cons, because when I try to think of pros and cons, I can only think of personal experiences i've had playing the game.  Like the time Michelangelo from TMNT was bit by a zombie and I didn't execute him for experimental reasons. (Mainly because I wanted to see the effects of a zombie bite on a mutated turtle.) While I was resting healing up my party, he turned and bit the RED Spy from TF2 and infected him. After putting Michelangelo down, I heard the RED Spy in my head."I don't wish to die and turn into one of those. Kill me."Truly, it was a hard moment in that playthrough. I think that is what's so fun about Organ Trail: the personal experiences and stories that derive from the gameplay. Very, very few games can say that many stories and reviews about the game derive from the gameplay.To put it in a short way: It's an old school, road trip zombie game that can't be missed, even for just one playthrough.And I guarentee that most players will have many more playthroughs than just one.10/10 Would experiment with a zombie bite on a turtle again.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Organ Trail is a knock off of the game "The Organ Trail" and honestly i like this one better. This game can actaully be quite funny. Having references from other video games like L4D2 and even Castlevania. This game is stylized as a retro RPG that would have looked like a game in the late 80's or early 90's. Lets start out with the game. There are two modes in this game.Campaign mode and endless mode. Im just going to ecplain the campaign. (since endless mode is self explanitory). You start off by meeting a priest name Clements (after shooting some zombies) then you go find your friends in Washington D.C. you get to name your friends as well as yourself (which is nice). Once you get to D.C. you have 15 or so hours to collect supplies because On the radio you overhear that there will be a nuclear strike. Clements finds your friends but then you have to put out Clements since he got bit by a zombie. So basically you are trying to get to your end destination and survive. On the way you can buy supplies, scacenge for supplies, and there will be mini games as well like avoidimg zombies while your in your car, killing bike gang members in your car and etc. there are also jobs you can do to get money and other misc. items. This game is very fun and i HIGHLY reccomend it. The only reason i wouldnt reccomend buying it is if your one of those people who talk crap about games that dont have great next-gen graphics. For me i love it, especially for its price ($4.99) Final Verdict:10/10 Go buy this game!!

Posted: January 2, 2016
												This is going to be a fairly tentative recommendation because this game actually succeeds a little too well in what it sets out to do, and it's somewhat detrimental to the whole experience. So it's the Oregon Trail but with Zombies, and it pulls that off expertly. A perfect parody/reimagining of the old edutainment classic that was on every school computer throughout the 1980's and 90's, and probably the most fun you were allowed to have in your school's computer lab before the internet became commonplace. You make a run from Washington, D.C. to a safe zone in Oregon protecting your band of survivors in the the post-Zombie-Apocolypse. You'll manage supplies for your survivors and your car, and play a bunch of minigames that allow for direct control over these scenarios, while having a metagame about time management and basic economics in order to excel at the scenario. The graphics are purposly lo-fi and retro, emulating the Apple II edition of Oregon Trail, and the music is actually pretty decent. It's not particularly difficult even on the harder settings, and any one run can be completed in an hour or two if you're quick about it and don't waste your resources. And therein lies the problem. Like with the original Oregon Trail, once you've done it once you've seen 90% of what the game has to offer, really. There are some extras, and there is an endless mode and unlocks in this now full version with all the DLC that add enough variation to the game to be a much fuller experience, but ultimately it's still the same Oregon Trail + Zombies game and it gets very repetitive very quickly (which is why the complete edition/DLC is so necessary - without the additional content the game gets overly repetitive within your first run-through). The advantage that the original PC hit had was an often captive audience: students who were bored in the library or computer lab had little else that might occupy their time, and so would load up another run to Oregon. But on your own time with thousands of other potential games on Steam to play, it's much harder to justify playing it again or repeatedly. I've gone through it twice now, and while I enjoyed my time with it, I'm doubting that I'll play it again for a year or so until I can remember that "oh, yeah, another run might be a good time waster for an evening!"I'd recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind a short game with low replayability, who loves The Walking Dead way too much, or kids who never had to play the original so they can play a version that's actually a bit more fun than it ever was. Past that it's a tough sell, though at least it's cheap.

Posted: April 1, 2013
												This game doesn't just claim to be Oregon Trail. It literally channels the ghost of that game so perfectly, you might forget that you aren't actually playing it.It's not just a cheesy ripoff either. It is faithful to the source material but it still maintains it's own unique aspects and introduces new "minigames". You still have to manage resources and scarcity. There is plenty of scavenging and trading. You're still at the helm of a wagon, but instead of fording rivers you have to ford throngs of zombies. Instead of snake bites there are zombie bites. You still can't carry back all the food.Oh, and there's lots of dysentery.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												Load up your station wagon and hit the road in an incredibly old-school, Oregon Trail inspired zombie apocalypse adventure. Organ Trail's simple goal, cross the U.S. and reach the Safe Haven, is kept lively and fresh by various events, mini-games, and choices along the way. You'll make tough decisions, manage your resources, and fend off zombies and bandits alike along the road. In towns you'll trade, take on jobs for resources or cash, and have the opportunity to train yourself in various expertise to help along the way, all while maintaining and upgrading your vehicle. The game has great replayability and, on top of that, it's easy on the wallet!10/10 Would put down a friend for breaking one too many mufflers again

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Organ Trail is a knock off of the game "The Organ Trail" and honestly i like this one better. This game can actaully be quite funny. Having references from other video games like L4D2 and even Castlevania. This game is stylized as a retro RPG that would have looked like a game in the late 80's or early 90's. Lets start out with the game. There are two modes in this game.Campaign mode and endless mode. Im just going to ecplain the campaign. (since endless mode is self explanitory). You start off by meeting a priest name Clements (after shooting some zombies) then you go find your friends in Washington D.C. you get to name your friends as well as yourself (which is nice). Once you get to D.C. you have 15 or so hours to collect supplies because On the radio you overhear that there will be a nuclear strike. Clements finds your friends but then you have to put out Clements since he got bit by a zombie. So basically you are trying to get to your end destination and survive. On the way you can buy supplies, scacenge for supplies, and there will be mini games as well like avoidimg zombies while your in your car, killing bike gang members in your car and etc. there are also jobs you can do to get money and other misc. items. This game is very fun and i HIGHLY reccomend it. The only reason i wouldnt reccomend buying it is if your one of those people who talk crap about games that dont have great next-gen graphics. For me i love it, especially for its price ($4.99) Final Verdict:10/10 Go buy this game!!

Posted: January 2, 2015
												What if I told you there was a game that was a perma-death story game with retro graphics and is a remake of the classic Oregon Trail with zombies?  Well, this is it. Organ Trail is definitely for those who want to play single player with a hit of multiplayerif you've got friends sitting next to you.  With a linear story line and different choices to make moral or otherwise you'll find a limited amount of replayability. Imput you're friends names into the game for increased entertainment and suspense. By yourself or with some friends sitting there you can spend time having some awesome adventures!Pros:  A decient SinglePlayer Experience remenisient of Oregon Trail   Decision managment integral to your survival  $5 (Or less on a sale)   Interactive minigames when scavaging, doing a job, or by sudden event immerses you  Difficult, but in a well done way (Difficulty setting and your decision making)Neutral:  Limited animations. I know it's to match Oregon Trail, but they could have improved it as well.  Decient Sound effects and sound track. Matches the content well though.Cons:  Difficult aiming controls ( try click and hold starting at zombie head and pull and let go at your feet)  You don't need to do the extra event things happening off the road  Limited replayability due to praticially non-existant story and linear path.  Ending level is a joke, but what ever. . .Final Suggestion:  Get it if you like difficult and retro nastalgic games. Posted: August 20, 2014
												Organ Trail a parody based on the once popular 70's educational game Oregon Trail. Organ Trail developed by The Men Who Wear Many Hats, sets you on a 6000 mile journey across America through a zombie ravaged wasteland where the player must manage their limited resources to reach a safe haven free of zombies. Organ trail is a brilliant game for the short time that you play it around (2-3 hours) depending on how fast you travel. However although there is a leaderboard so you can replay the game and beat your highscore, replay value is low and I wouldn't go back to it more than twice. 7.5/10

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I... really can't recommend this game, even for the low, low price for which I got it. I can be told that I'm "missing the point," but frankly... I really recommend just playing Oregon Trail. It's a similar experience, but slightly more enjoyable.The problem is that most of the time, this just felt unfair to me, in ways that a game should not be. Allow me to elaborate: I was playing on EASY, because I KNEW this game would be hard. And NONE of the minigames felt like a DECENT challenge. They were either so easy as to be pointless, or difficult to the point of frustration (like the shootouts with bandits who never miss and barely ever pop out of cover... Time Crisis felt more fair to me, and that's a game that's designed to EAT QUARTERS.) Every now and then, an interesting event would happen, but more often something would just be taken from me for no reason, and I had to accept it. No strategy, no rhyme or reason. I literally once picked up 3 cans of fuel as a raandom event and IMMEDIATELY had 4 stolen from me by bandits.And these bandits are the scourge of the gods. They are always teeming, always a threat, no matter how many you strike down, and are seemingly unaffected by zombies and hold no valuables, even bullets, that do not disintegrate once slain. They can steal fuel from the tank of a moving vehicle. They can kidnap a party member (again, from a moving vehicle) and hold him at gunpoint to force a single shot rescue with no grace on the aim; you LITERALLY have to be PERFECT.The game just makes it feel like you have no control over... anything. And not in the realistic way. Shops and jobs rarely offer what you need, ammo and fuel are insanely overpriced, your party members are mentally deficient enough to break spare parts for the car on a regular basis... and unless you have an $80 perk, you can only find food, scrap, and (I believe, rarely) ammo while scavenging. And I was only ever able to learn the perk that allowed me to find medkits.In short... I found this game just frutrating and disappointing. Maybe if you're a ridiculously huge zombie fanatic, it'll be more fun. Otherwise, I think Oregon Trail is just better-designed, and all the little "jokes" and references can be read for just as much effect. The game has potential, but it just feels like it doesn't offer enough. Nothing bad that happened to me (okay, save one gunshot wound that I quickly patched with my dozens of medkits) seemed like it happened as a result of my input... that much lack of control, where you can (seemingly easily) lose through no fault of your own, just doesn't appeal to me.

Posted: April 8, 2015
												As a child of the 80's I played a ton of OREGON trail during 'computer class' in Elementary & Middle school.That game was great for its time. But I wouldnt be to terribly excited to sit down and have to play it again (likely on a Commodore, for that authentic 1991 feel!).However, ORGAN Trail takes everything that made it's spiritual precursor great and leaves all that learning bologne behind.At its core, the game is a resource management Sim, but it's really so much more than that.It's an escape from the reality of the real world for a few moments.Are you a teacher who busts her/his butt at work all day? Name your party after your snot-nosed students and laugh heartily when they get torn to shreds.Are you a seasoned mechanic who enjoys gaming in your free time? Well now you can work on turning a pixelated station wagon into a Zombie Killing machine, complete with machine gun mounted steel reinforced windows.Are you a stocks and bonds broker who would like to see what happens when you corner the market on canned goods and bullets and leave everyone else to try and barter for your stash with weird green money from better times?WELL NOW YOU CAN!ORGAN Trail has all of this and more!I named my party after my family. Not only did they get dysentary, but they got shot by bandits, bikers attempts to steal car parts from them, and they were chewed up and spit back out by zombie bears in the woods!Seriously, this game is hilarious -- and the soundtrack is t1ts!

Posted: June 14, 2015
												Have you ever played Oregon Trail and thought, "Man. This sure could use more zombies." Well, you're in luck! Presenting Organ Trail. A game that plays similar to the old classic but is still unique. Try to get you and your party to the supposed Safe Haven in the West without getting bitten, broken or dying to desentry. There are stops along the where you can trade, sell, buy and take jobs for things as well as stopping any ol' where to scavenge. Just be careful! Those zombies aren't too friends. Nor are the dear and biker gangs that sometimes chase after you. There are no oxen to worry about. Just a station wagon that has seen better days. It has a health bar so make sure you keep it in good condition otherwise things on it are more likely to break and cause you problems. When you find auto shops, try your best to get ahold of Upgrades. Those will work wonders on your car and help it and you make it across the land. Don't forget to rest up your party too! The lower their health, the more likely they are to break something or contract something, become incapacitated, and die. Sometimes they can be bitten by zombies and as long as you can keep their health up, they won't turn. I still kill them anyway though. I don't trust them. >_> All in all this game feels like the classic with a new twist. The graphics are old, the music is chiptune and the story is belovedly post apocalytic and fantastic. Play. This. Game! P.S. Anyone know what this game means when it says "dicking"? As in "Gertie is dicking around with 12 ammo and accidentally ruins it." It sound sexual but I doubt it really is.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												TL;DR is at the bottom.First let me say that there IS a mobile version of this for slightly cheaper, If I knew this before I bought it I would have bought the mobile version simply because it suits mobile gaming better in my opinion.Recently I've found it pretty hard for games to hold my attention, this however, this was a pleasant exception.I've always enjoyed micromanagement in video games, so this looked interesting to me. This isn't really the same, and not just because it has Zombies. I doubt anyone is thinking this, but don't buy this JUST because you wanna play a game similar to the Oregon Trail. It's a fun experience that involves travelling across the country in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ car that falls apart all the time and causes you to break your legs for no reason. As you travel random events occur where you'll either need to make a descision or something happens which is out of your control. Things like losing health for a character or losing/gaining a certain resource. There are set towns that you go by and can stock up on supplies or upgrade your car or character. You can also do jobs, these usually consist of a minigame which can be different depending on the scenario. The minigames are quite fun in my opinion, but it's a little tough to get used to the shooting mechanics. The minigames also apear in other situations and some minigames even have suprises lying in them. I won't spoil the encounters but some are quite rare and may suprise you. This game is pretty cheap, but depending on your budget I'd wait for it to go on sale.TL;DR - If you like making descisions and playing some minigames, buy this. Maybe wait for it to be on sale.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Hey it's Tanner from Steampunks, https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCfEBvwc4__gT8s65lnTwyhQJust finished my first run of "Organ Trail" and I couldn't be more satisfied. Like many Canadians I have fond memories of playing Trans Canada Highway (the Canadian Oregon Trail about truck drivers). This was a blast from the text based past, with enough humor and originality to keep anyone playing. A single run can last for hours and the game is built around replayability. There's always something to interact with, and it could mean life or death. I would recommend this to anyone who liked "Oregon Trail" or "TCH", and it's a no brainer purchase while on sale.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Oh man, this game is awesome.Together, with my trusty companions: Banana, Ann, sux, and <3, we went to travel from the east coast to the west coast, trying to get through hordes of zombies and the occasional jackass kids taking advantage of the situation. We didn't make it. <3 Died pretty early because she was bit by a zombie so I had to kill her before she became a threat to the rest of us. We also encountered like 4 towns with no ammo in a row. Bad luck, I guess.BUT, WHO CARES ABOUT THE LIVES OF THOSE FOOLS ANYWAY? The game is great. I'm sure you're familiar with Oregon Trail, a timeless classic of a family escaping to the west. Well this game is that game, but much more hilarious, with obvious nods to the original. I mean, there's a boss battle with a zombie bear for starters. You also need to fix your Station Wagon from time to time. And ♥♥♥♥ing tires are always getting stolen or broken. God. I lost like 8 tires in less than half the total route. The game is terrifically fun, though. Despite it not being super action packed, the game offers a lot of decisions. And it's decisions that make someone a good gamer at the end of the day, right? I mean, do you want to rest up your team or try to get along to the next town at 30% health? What if you get intercepted by a biker gang for the 30th time? That could be unfortunate. Oh, or what if there's a horde of zombies that you can't avoid because your tire broke again? You just never know what kind of sillyness can happen, so you have to be prepared. But don't be too prepared, because there's tons of bandits who like to steal mufflers which you stocked up on because it seems like something to stock up on... but you never did need to replace any. Oh yeah, and you should totally buy food, maybe you should sell those mufflers you got from that last town for helping a family survive a shoot out or whatever was going on, you didn't read the job description, you just wanted to get paid. Oh. You can't sell those? Oh. Oh. Oh...At least you get to kill zombies and survive until your wagon reaches the west coast somewhere.
