Posted: December 26, 2013
												If you remember playing this classic game of migration, survival, and the dangers of the undead apocalypse when you were a kid (probably, if you're like me, on your school's Apple IIe or the like), you'll be glad to know this faithful recreation brings to life every single detail of this epic childhood favorite.  From foraging for food while shooting zombie bears, to trading on the open road, to putting down your best friend because he stole your food or tried to rip your face off, every second will bring feelings of nostalgia, as well as the pleasant feeling of having survived nightmares that would drive most men mad.  Will you make it to the promised land of Safe Haven, or are you just another tombstone waiting to happen?Don't forget to bring bullets, partner.  The Organ Trail awaits.In terms of playability, the game is very fun, requiring a very smooth learning curve (and it'll even give you a tutorial at the beginning), and providing a lot of easy selections.In terms of graphics, this is a recreation of an Apple II/iIe/similar game (that really existed, seriously, just ask my cousin here who has some real estate in Florida to sell you), so the graphics are going to look like that Apple IIe feeling.  That means 16 colors, strong contrasts, black almost everywhere, and great blocky pixel graphics.The sound even comes off feeling the same, beeps and bloops faithfully rebuilt using the highest of technology.If you want to recreate that seriously old-school feeling, and want to relive the great trials of these pioneers as they made their way from the eastern shorelines to the west coast, while avoiding the Nuclear Fallout zones and the hordes of ravenous undead, then I would not hesitate to play this game.

												There's good and bad with this one, but I'm pretty happy with it. It's a really good re-imagining of Oregon Trail 1 (for those of us old enough to have played the hell out of that game back in elementary school), and it's got some nice updates to make it fun for an adult audience as well. Since it's aimed at adults with nostalgia value, it's also fairly difficult (at least compared to Oregon Trail).That being said, there are some downpoints. 1.) it's still fairy buggy -- right now my save seems to be stuck somewhere in the desert because the game stopped for an event that never came, so my care is just sitting there. 2.) shooting is very finicky, but once you get the hang of it (it takes awhile), it's not so bad.All in all, I'd definitely recommend it, especially if it goes on sale. Plus, you get the added bonus of naming your party members after friends and then pointing and laughing when they die of choler --- I mean, zombism.

												"Organ Trail: Director's Cut" is a neat little spin-off of the game "Oregan Trail", takes the latter's core design elements and incorporates them into a zombie apocalypse setting where your goal is now to reach Safe Haven on the eastern coast of the USA and stay alive during the trip. 												Great fun! I wasn't sure about it at first, and the aiming mechanic is a bit weird when you're used to RPG/FPS style.It stays true to both the "Oregon Trail" game and "Kill Zombies!!" theme in a fun way.Drive your (Station) Wagon across the US to settle in a new (uninfected) city. But be careful, perils and dangers lie between here and there: dystentary, typhoid, starvation, injury, (zombie bites), Indian (bandit) attacks, and more. Plan carefully, for you'll need food, fuel, med kits, and spare parts a plenty in your cross-country jaunt--and you may need them too far from the next landmark or city.Hint: A party member with a zombie bite apparently doesn't usually turn until their health zeros out... I didn't read that part and just... well I shot The Doctor in the face.Fun for all ages! :P

Posted: December 16, 2013
												When I was a kid, if you were lucky you got to spend a few minutes playing a computer game, in which you would die of dysentery almost immediately and start to wish you were playing something else.  And because of how the title of the game was pronounced, we called it "The Organ Trail".  And it was a classic game, and might have been for many the first introduction to computer strategy games and historical simulation.  This isn't that game.  But it's so close, it's as though that game rose from the grave to finish consuming our brains.  The Organ Trail take the same gameplay as The Oregon Trail, but changes the premise to an exodus of survivors during a zombie apocalypse, traveling the country in a beat-up station wagon while trying to reach a safe haven on the west coast.  It is a parody, but it also plays well with two exceptions.  The shooting mechanic is frustrating beyond belief.  I can barely remember how hunting was handled in The Oregon Trail, but here it is a mess.  And since shooting is now about survival against attack instead of gathering food, a good shooting system would have been welcome.  And the bandit minigame that comes up is awkward.  This game pretty much requires you play it with a mouse, no touchpads if you want to survive.  The achievements are also buggy.  Sometimes the counters reset randomly during a game.  But for those who remember playing the old Oregon Trail, and those with a dark sense of humor, or zombie fans, this is a fun game.

Posted: May 21, 2015
												This is a hilarious spin off of the classic game Oregon Trail. I loved it. With all the same danger that was in Oregon trail, but the twist that the danger comes from zombies and not... well... mother nature. It's a simple game where you just have to make sure you have enough supplies to make your way across the country to the safe zone with your friends. Often times friends will die and you will not be able to stop it. One time three of my people were dragged out of my car and eaten alive.  The random aspect of it can be annoying, but the game is also very funny. Stop and talk to people along the way and see what they have to say. They might surprise you.

Posted: May 19, 2015
												Pros: -Classic 8-bit arcade-style feel.-Awesome backdrop of a zombie apocalypse.- Has some of the same basic aspects as the awesome original game, “Oregon Trail”, with the main objective being to survive. However there are many differences.-Offers interactions for trading, scavenging, repairing your station wagon, training to acquire skills, and doing jobs to earn supplies or money. -There are multiple instances where your choices affect the gameplay.-Fantastically dark sense of humor.-Getting to name your fellow survivors after your worst enemies and watching them get bit by a zombie while going to the bathroom, then putting them down before they turn. Cons: -Somewhat challenging gameplay, even on the easy difficulty setting. Expect multiple playthroughs before you get the hang of it.-Annoying combat controls that usually result in getting attacked or wasting ammo until you get used to it.Overall, a really challenging and exciting game that is really fun to play and totally worth the buy.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												TL;DR is at the bottom.First let me say that there IS a mobile version of this for slightly cheaper, If I knew this before I bought it I would have bought the mobile version simply because it suits mobile gaming better in my opinion.Recently I've found it pretty hard for games to hold my attention, this however, this was a pleasant exception.I've always enjoyed micromanagement in video games, so this looked interesting to me. This isn't really the same, and not just because it has Zombies. I doubt anyone is thinking this, but don't buy this JUST because you wanna play a game similar to the Oregon Trail. It's a fun experience that involves travelling across the country in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ car that falls apart all the time and causes you to break your legs for no reason. As you travel random events occur where you'll either need to make a descision or something happens which is out of your control. Things like losing health for a character or losing/gaining a certain resource. There are set towns that you go by and can stock up on supplies or upgrade your car or character. You can also do jobs, these usually consist of a minigame which can be different depending on the scenario. The minigames are quite fun in my opinion, but it's a little tough to get used to the shooting mechanics. The minigames also apear in other situations and some minigames even have suprises lying in them. I won't spoil the encounters but some are quite rare and may suprise you. This game is pretty cheap, but depending on your budget I'd wait for it to go on sale.TL;DR - If you like making descisions and playing some minigames, buy this. Maybe wait for it to be on sale.

Posted: September 29, 2013
												A very interesting take on the old "Oregon Trail" game.  A zombie survival game using the same template.  You need ammo, food, fuel, medical bags, etc....  You also need to maintain your vehicle.  You start at one end of the United States and have to make your way to the West coast.  Within each town you can find jobs or people to barter with.  There is still money, so you can just buy what you need, but it is expensive.  There is a bonus game after you finish the story.  A pretty interesting little game.

Posted: May 12, 2014
												Zombies are IN for quite a while now and this game has been around for a few years as well. It was originally made as a parody of Oregon Trail, a really old game that had numerous re-releases (it was made in 1971 and had like 10 incarnations so far) that allowed a player to experience the settling in western United States. Organ Trail was a free flash/browser game that had a lot of fans, so the creators started a Kickstarter campaign to make a Director's Cut as a fully commercial title. After the funds were collected the game was made and is now available for Steam and mobile devices.As the game starts you are given a station wagon with some limited supplies (food, scrap for car repairs, a few spare tires, mufflers, car batteries, medical kits...) and 4 companions. Your goal: reach safe haven at the west and survive the zombie apocalypse. The whole game is set around random events that occur as you travel from one city/settlement to another while scavenging supplies, trading with other people, fighting off zombie attacks, escaping gangs that are after your supplies etc. Each hour that passes (in a matter of 2 seconds) is a possible trigger for a random event and they vary from simple weather changes that can slow you down to encounters with all kinds of people (these trigger classic text adventure kind of stories).Settlements offer a place to rest and trade and you can also get a job to earn some more supplies or money (arcade shootouts with zombies or bandits). Each city has a car shop that can upgrade your station wagon or a combat school to enhance your own abilities. Don't forget to refuel as well or you will get stranded in the middle of nowhere and forced to trade when you don't really want to.The game looks and feels as if it was made in early 1980s and that gives it a specific charm. But don't let it turn you away! Seriously, it's kinda cute to have such a game in 2014 (or 2012, when it was made), a game that relies on gameplay rather than on awesome graphics. It's a lot of fun with all those events that may or may not occur, but it does have its limits. I completed it 4-5 times and it lost its charm - once you figure out the best way to gather supplies, when and where to sell them and what to buy instead - it gets real easy. True, there are difficulty levels but even the hardest one is hard only at the start. As for the zombie combat, I'll give you a tip: when you want to shoot a zombie click on the zombie and hold the mouse button as you drag it towards your avatar. It's a direct hit in 95% of cases.I haven't played the mobile version (I got it as well, but I just never cared much for mobile games) so I can't say much about it. From what I saw online it's quite popular and people who own it love it! Give this game a chance, it's fun even though it's very limited.

The game takes also a little bit from the comic/tv series of The Walking Dead. Almost everything is random generated, except the main path in the campaign mode. Posted: November 25, 2014
												PROS:Great parody of Oregon Trail while adding new mechanics.Fitting graphics and music.Lots of tongue-in-cheek humor and zombie culture references. (can be hit or miss)Delicate resource management balance.Multiple difficulty levels.Secret interactions near Halloween.Good game for the price, even better when on sale.CONS:Luck of the dice at higher difficulties. May want to roll a new team if you get really unlucky right at the start.Steep initial learning curve, particularly with shooting.Achievement progress will reset randomly.A car repair action seems to happen -a lot- less often than stated success percentages suggest.Other thoughts:Shooting takes a minute to get used to. I find that dragging from the zombie's head to my character's belt buckle is the best option for me.Getting really good at shooting will allow you to dominate lower difficulties.You can complete 90% of the recovery jobs without shooting a single bullet, just go right!

Posted: July 2, 2014
												For those that never experienced old Apple 2 style games, most of this game's charm and humor will be lost on you.  But for those that sat in the computer lab, mindlessly clicking away, this game is a rare treat and a crystal ball looking back into your childhood.  Many take to adding in names of their friends, but for me, I always added Spiderman, Batman, etc.  And it's very telling when Bruce Wayne crumples up money and destroys it out of boredom.  Rich b***ard.  While some of the key controls, IE shooting are bass-akwards, it didn't stop me from enjoying other parts of the game.While there is a working form of this game online, it doesn't have half the features of this game.  Do yourself a favor.  Get the full version and support the devs.  They gotta eat too.Pros:+Nostalgic look back at the old Oregon Trail game you played in school+Interesting easter eggs located at nearly every checkpoint (From Final Fantasy, to Last of Us, to Shaun of the Dead, and more)+Randomized events give high replay+Interesting Achievements add another degree of difficulty (Can you make it without any money?  What about no trading? etc.)+Good soundtrack mixed with old-school sound effects+Endless mode makes it so you can unlock new starter modes!Cons:-God awful inverted gun controls with no settings to change to normal-Glitchy counter, making certain achievements a course in futility -Zombie 'Boss Fights' are more of an exercise in running away than fighting off the undead.-Clements isn't around longer.Read all this way?  You deserve a treat.  Don't bring your friends to a zom-pocolypse.  Bring Chuck Norris.  Seriously.  Bring him.

Posted: December 26, 2014
												From what little I've played, Organ Trail manages to be a relatively complex game within effective and well-crafted, albeit simplistic, graphics and audio (that are so in order to remind of the original Oregon Trail). You could lose a lot of hours to it whether you're searching for a way to pass the time or a game that challenges your skills for things like planning ahead. Not a steep learning curve at all, and the little touches the developers add (i.e., Halloween mode, tombstones, various references to pop culture) are nice. I've only noticed a couple bugs, and none of them affected the gameplay enough for me to be seriously bothered.

												Organ Trail is a post-apocalypse version of the very old game called "Oregon Trail" back in the early 90's and so forth, albeit this game has a twist over the previous.Your objective is similar but is added with the fun addition of zombies and other variables, the objective of the game is to make your way across the vast USA wasteland collecting food and other resources, fighting through hordes of zombies, killing bandits, and to finally reach the 'Safe Haven' with hopefully all your team.The gameplay is quite linear although it is designed to be so, asides from being a bit linear it is quite a fun game on the first few run-throughs, and is usually better played with friends either IRL or on Steam/Skype chat as it gives a feeling to them being worth something in-game.The game can be quite brutal at times often making you lose resources and possibly lose team-mates, the random events can be quite devestating also leading to the unlikely death of you or your team-mates.Overall this game is a very fun game to play 8/10It has fair replay value but after awhile it gets quite boring but nonetheless something that'll keep you occupied on a streak without internet(Power cut, travelling, etc. )

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Organ Trail: Director's Cut is a surprisingly entertaining and fun game. It pays homage to the original Organ Trail and places it into the grime world of a zombie apocaplyse. The game consists of traveling across country and keeping yourself and your crew alive as long as possible. The plot is thus your own journey and your own interpretation of the visuals and events that take place. There are many unexpected events that can occur during a playthrough which gives this game high replayability (one playthrough can last a couple of hours). The gameplay is good, but it does require you to learn a lot of it on your own. It's also a bit of a hard game. Shooting your gun requires you to drag and click the mouse which can be difficult. The game doesn't force you to do certain tasks and the freedom was a nice change gaming wise. The music is entertaining and fitting. Like the game, it's a mixture of humor and even a bit melancholy. The graphics are pixelated and minimal, which seemed to go well with game's theme and origin. It's really good and original for an indie game. If you liked the original game, like zombie lore, or like games with strategy I would highly recommend.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I... really can't recommend this game, even for the low, low price for which I got it. I can be told that I'm "missing the point," but frankly... I really recommend just playing Oregon Trail. It's a similar experience, but slightly more enjoyable.The problem is that most of the time, this just felt unfair to me, in ways that a game should not be. Allow me to elaborate: I was playing on EASY, because I KNEW this game would be hard. And NONE of the minigames felt like a DECENT challenge. They were either so easy as to be pointless, or difficult to the point of frustration (like the shootouts with bandits who never miss and barely ever pop out of cover... Time Crisis felt more fair to me, and that's a game that's designed to EAT QUARTERS.) Every now and then, an interesting event would happen, but more often something would just be taken from me for no reason, and I had to accept it. No strategy, no rhyme or reason. I literally once picked up 3 cans of fuel as a raandom event and IMMEDIATELY had 4 stolen from me by bandits.And these bandits are the scourge of the gods. They are always teeming, always a threat, no matter how many you strike down, and are seemingly unaffected by zombies and hold no valuables, even bullets, that do not disintegrate once slain. They can steal fuel from the tank of a moving vehicle. They can kidnap a party member (again, from a moving vehicle) and hold him at gunpoint to force a single shot rescue with no grace on the aim; you LITERALLY have to be PERFECT.The game just makes it feel like you have no control over... anything. And not in the realistic way. Shops and jobs rarely offer what you need, ammo and fuel are insanely overpriced, your party members are mentally deficient enough to break spare parts for the car on a regular basis... and unless you have an $80 perk, you can only find food, scrap, and (I believe, rarely) ammo while scavenging. And I was only ever able to learn the perk that allowed me to find medkits.In short... I found this game just frutrating and disappointing. Maybe if you're a ridiculously huge zombie fanatic, it'll be more fun. Otherwise, I think Oregon Trail is just better-designed, and all the little "jokes" and references can be read for just as much effect. The game has potential, but it just feels like it doesn't offer enough. Nothing bad that happened to me (okay, save one gunshot wound that I quickly patched with my dozens of medkits) seemed like it happened as a result of my input... that much lack of control, where you can (seemingly easily) lose through no fault of your own, just doesn't appeal to me.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												This is a pretty awesome game for those who have made memories with Oregon Trail, those who are looking for retro graphics, those who like zombies, and those who enjoy satire towards any of those things. Pros-Great Humor: (If you are a zombie fanatic, and have watched every zombie movie, played every zombie game, and read every zombie comic book, then you will pick up on all of the excellent humor sprinkled throughout this game. On top of that, there are a ton of nods to just older games in general, which is always awesome.)-Retro Graphics: (A plus if you like them)-Replayable: (If you only play through this once, you will only see about 10% of the humor, challenges, etc. Each playthrough yields different things, such as events, and you can take a different approach everytime. You can stock up on different items, strive to do different things, and changing your sense of morality at anytime. The only really linear thing in this game is the path. You go from Point A, then Point B, all the way to Point Z, which is the safe haven you are trying to get to. It is what happens on your way to each point that makes this game interesting.)-Soundtrack: (This game has a really good sense of approach towards the situations you may be in, and one of the big reasons I say that is the soundtrack. The game always has fitting music, and good music at that.)Cons-Gameplay: (This is a subjective con. The gameplay is interesting in that it really is true to how an older game like this would play. But that doesn't mean it is easy. My only complaint on this is the aiming. Considering you must fight off the undead with a ranged weapon, you HAVE to be good at aiming it. On top of that, you can't waste ammo, as it could be out of reach due to price, or the shear lack of it in the zombie wastelands you explore. The aiming is...weird. I suggest looking up a video of gameplay so you can see if you can cope with it. I've gotten used to it, but at the same time I shouldn't have to. Gameplay should be fluid and creative, yet natural. Honestly, I would like just one of those, but aside from this one con, if you can overcome this one annoyance, then this game is definitely worth it.)Verdict Everything about this game is near-perfect, aside from one thing. Gameplay. While everything else is so good, this is a big thing to do deal with since without gameplay, it wouldn't be a game. At the same time, you have to see if it would bother you so I suggest looking at a video of the gameplay to decide. If, afterwards, you decide that isn't too bad, then nothing else should be stopping you from getting this game aside from lacking the funds to do so. Everything aligns almost perfectly for this game but one thing, so decide from all of this if you would truely like it.P.S. There is also a mobile edition available for Android and iOS, so if you want to try this game but feel playing it with a mouse is a deal breaker, then that is the next best thing. The one thing both editions have over the free, Facebook alternative is that they are much more complete, and have A TON of addition content that adds to the experience of this game. The developer did fairly well on this title, so I trusted the mobile edition would live up to the PC edition here. Long story short, there is no game that really keeps itself consistent across all the platforms it's available on so well like this one!

Posted: November 1, 2014
												If you like zombies, text based (or text heavy?), and don't mind starting from the beginning in a game over and over, you'll like Organ Trail. I was never lucky enough to play Oregon Trail as a kid, so any puns that are from that game I've missed. But I a VERY big zombie fan, and have played many zombie games and watched many a zombie movie. Organ trail has a lot of easter eggs that reference zombies in pop culture, whether it's from the screens that show you what town you've made it to, or even within the text itself. Off the top of my head, I remember this game referencing The Walking Dead, Zombies Ate My Neighbors, and Resident Evil! The humor in this game is pretty light, which is needed because the random events can stress you out. It has with me, but once I get a pop up saying that 'someone farted', I smirk. Gameplay wise, it's pretty easy. Most of this is text based, with the exception of boss battles and side quests (shooting bandits, scavenging, grabbing forgotten items for people, and killing zombies for people). I have a wild imagination so this isn't a problem for me, but if you're the type that needs to see what's going on in a game, then that may not be so awesome for you. I have noticed spelling and grammar errors in the special events that are strictly text based. A little embarassing honestly. It took me a while to learn how to shoot right, and while it's not a horrible system for shooting, it really could be better. It's hard to shoot zombies when you're using a laptop mouse pad. It would have been cool to have melee weapons as an alternative to the shooting system, but that may be a part of Oregon Trail nostalgia/referencing that I don't get.I have spent way too much time playing this game, but that's not stopping me. This game really is worth the five dollars though. The replay value is pretty solid, as this is a solid game.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Organ Trail is a remake or Oregon Trail (that game everyone played in 4th grade computer class) with zombies, because everything these days must have zombies. The player manages supplies and health while rolling across America in a station wagon and making pit stops at settlements, where the player can do jobs for additional supplies. If you've played Oregon Trail, you pretty much know what to expect. It's a short game that can be completed in about two or three hours if you don't die, but you might be inclined to playthrough a few more times, though not much changes. The main difference from Oregon Trail is the zombie combat. It's simple and rather clunky, but it fits the style of the game well. The game is a fair challenge on normal mode, but should be manageable to most players as long as they are careful. For five dollars, Organ Trail is worth the money.

Posted: August 13, 2013
												Even if Organ Trail started as a parody of The Oregon Trail in its original form, this Director's Cut has seen it expanded in many ways that certainly make it stand out as a game by itself and not just a derivative parody, as noteworthy as that may be. Giving you control over a particular survivor and his additional party of four, along with your reliable Station Wagon, in the zombie apocalypse and tasking you to get from East  Coast to West Coast of the United States, Organ Trail lets you handle the minutia and logistics of such an endeavor - from managing your party's resources like food and spare car parts to determining how you will handle various events and people you run into, as well as the act of combat against the zombies themselves. Controls probably could've used some updating given the times, but that peculiar "genre kitchen sink" feeling that made the original game so interesting is largely untouched and still effective.

												Organ Trail is a post-apocalypse version of the very old game called "Oregon Trail" back in the early 90's and so forth, albeit this game has a twist over the previous.Your objective is similar but is added with the fun addition of zombies and other variables, the objective of the game is to make your way across the vast USA wasteland collecting food and other resources, fighting through hordes of zombies, killing bandits, and to finally reach the 'Safe Haven' with hopefully all your team.The gameplay is quite linear although it is designed to be so, asides from being a bit linear it is quite a fun game on the first few run-throughs, and is usually better played with friends either IRL or on Steam/Skype chat as it gives a feeling to them being worth something in-game.The game can be quite brutal at times often making you lose resources and possibly lose team-mates, the random events can be quite devestating also leading to the unlikely death of you or your team-mates.Overall this game is a very fun game to play 8/10It has fair replay value but after awhile it gets quite boring but nonetheless something that'll keep you occupied on a streak without internet(Power cut, travelling, etc. )

Posted: November 25, 2016
												How can I explain how much I enjoy this game? I know! I bought it twice. Yes, bought twice. First time on iOS when it first came out, then again on Steam about a week after I joined. And I was glad to do it.Organ Trail isn't original; it's an homage. It's a bizarre, hilarious, utterly enjoyable take on the classic Apple IIe Oregon Trail. You remember: the one where everyone died of dysentery and you were left wondering just what the heck a "wagon tongue" was. Well, you trade in the Conestoga wagon for a station wagon (which bears a strong resemblance to Clark Griswold's Family Truckster, or possibly a Plymouth Reliant K) and instead of hunting buffalo, you're shooting zombies. The sound, graphics, and gameplay are all so close to the original Oregon trail that you're going to have elementary school flashbacks. (Since they have such a sense of humor, clicking in-game buttons has a sound effect: the distinctive CLUNK of a IIe keyboard.) The one and ONLY one slight ding against it is the repair minigame, but you know, that's totally forgiveable. Just because it's not my cup of tea doesn't mean it was a bad design choice or really a problem with the game. Every game has a feature or two you're not particularly fond of. Tremendous replay value, practically guaranteed hilarity, and outstanding minigames. And, of course, dysentery.

Posted: October 30, 2015
												I have put a considerably large amount of time into this game and I can say that it is worth the money you pay for it, unless you are charged £40 or something. The game is a zombie-fied version of the educational game classic 'The Oregan Trail' something I've only ever really heard about through other people, and not something I've had a great deal of experiance with. Even not having any nostalgia for the original version I still manage to derive an insane amount of enjoyment from this game. It's basically a simulation of you and four friends trying to make your way across a zombie infested America, starting in Washington DC and ending on the west coast in a place called safe haven.The gameplay is quite slow and steady for the most part, with a great deal of the decisions being based around how much time to put into different activities to supply yourself for the journey, however another equally large part of the gameplay is scavenging for resources in the wilderness and fighting of enemies in different styles of combat encounters. The game has a great sense of humor and has a lot going for it, especially when combined with the final cut expansion pack, which adds more encounters and bosses as well as more missions and an entire character skin system not present in the game originally. The only major issue with the game as a whole is that it can be quite buggy, some achievements tend not to work and getting the game to unlock certain bonuses can be a complete nightmare, but in fairness to the devs it was made by two people only and they really do try their best to get everything fixed and working for everyone. TL;DR:A great take on a classic title that suffers from a few minor bug issues.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												What if I told you there was a game that was a perma-death story game with retro graphics and is a remake of the classic Oregon Trail with zombies?  Well, this is it. Organ Trail is definitely for those who want to play single player with a hit of multiplayerif you've got friends sitting next to you.  With a linear story line and different choices to make moral or otherwise you'll find a limited amount of replayability. Imput you're friends names into the game for increased entertainment and suspense. By yourself or with some friends sitting there you can spend time having some awesome adventures!Pros:  A decient SinglePlayer Experience remenisient of Oregon Trail   Decision managment integral to your survival  $5 (Or less on a sale)   Interactive minigames when scavaging, doing a job, or by sudden event immerses you  Difficult, but in a well done way (Difficulty setting and your decision making)Neutral:  Limited animations. I know it's to match Oregon Trail, but they could have improved it as well.  Decient Sound effects and sound track. Matches the content well though.Cons:  Difficult aiming controls ( try click and hold starting at zombie head and pull and let go at your feet)  You don't need to do the extra event things happening off the road  Limited replayability due to praticially non-existant story and linear path.  Ending level is a joke, but what ever. . .Final Suggestion:  Get it if you like difficult and retro nastalgic games. Posted: April 8, 2015
												As a child of the 80's I played a ton of OREGON trail during 'computer class' in Elementary & Middle school.That game was great for its time. But I wouldnt be to terribly excited to sit down and have to play it again (likely on a Commodore, for that authentic 1991 feel!).However, ORGAN Trail takes everything that made it's spiritual precursor great and leaves all that learning bologne behind.At its core, the game is a resource management Sim, but it's really so much more than that.It's an escape from the reality of the real world for a few moments.Are you a teacher who busts her/his butt at work all day? Name your party after your snot-nosed students and laugh heartily when they get torn to shreds.Are you a seasoned mechanic who enjoys gaming in your free time? Well now you can work on turning a pixelated station wagon into a Zombie Killing machine, complete with machine gun mounted steel reinforced windows.Are you a stocks and bonds broker who would like to see what happens when you corner the market on canned goods and bullets and leave everyone else to try and barter for your stash with weird green money from better times?WELL NOW YOU CAN!ORGAN Trail has all of this and more!I named my party after my family. Not only did they get dysentary, but they got shot by bandits, bikers attempts to steal car parts from them, and they were chewed up and spit back out by zombie bears in the woods!Seriously, this game is hilarious -- and the soundtrack is t1ts!

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Organ Trail is a unique throw-back parody type of the original Oregon Trail game. The idea behind the game is you are in a station wagon fleeing through the zombie apocalypse. It features everything an original Oregon Trailer game would have including trading, hunting and random events.The game does a good job capturing the old-school vibe but at the end of the day doesn't really hold up. It's an okay playthrough the first time but there's really no reason to go back. It's a good game for a "goof" or if you really love the zombie genre but overall the game could be a lot more.Replay value is pretty low and I wouldn't recommend the game.Genre Lovers: Skip itNon-Genre Lovers: Skip itTime To Beat: ~1 hour (low replay value)

Posted: August 13, 2013
												Even if Organ Trail started as a parody of The Oregon Trail in its original form, this Director's Cut has seen it expanded in many ways that certainly make it stand out as a game by itself and not just a derivative parody, as noteworthy as that may be. Giving you control over a particular survivor and his additional party of four, along with your reliable Station Wagon, in the zombie apocalypse and tasking you to get from East  Coast to West Coast of the United States, Organ Trail lets you handle the minutia and logistics of such an endeavor - from managing your party's resources like food and spare car parts to determining how you will handle various events and people you run into, as well as the act of combat against the zombies themselves. Controls probably could've used some updating given the times, but that peculiar "genre kitchen sink" feeling that made the original game so interesting is largely untouched and still effective.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												Load up your station wagon and hit the road in an incredibly old-school, Oregon Trail inspired zombie apocalypse adventure. Organ Trail's simple goal, cross the U.S. and reach the Safe Haven, is kept lively and fresh by various events, mini-games, and choices along the way. You'll make tough decisions, manage your resources, and fend off zombies and bandits alike along the road. In towns you'll trade, take on jobs for resources or cash, and have the opportunity to train yourself in various expertise to help along the way, all while maintaining and upgrading your vehicle. The game has great replayability and, on top of that, it's easy on the wallet!10/10 Would put down a friend for breaking one too many mufflers again

												This game is super good and takes skill to master! The game is based on you are 4 friends and your trying to get to safety from a zombie apocolypse that has occured in North America. As you drive from city to city, town to town, you encounter different activities. Such as choosing risky options or fighting zombies from the roof of your car. 												This game doesn't just claim to be Oregon Trail. It literally channels the ghost of that game so perfectly, you might forget that you aren't actually playing it.It's not just a cheesy ripoff either. I scavanged 10 times in a row, traded every chance i got, and couldn't find fuel anywhere. I had a multitude of food, scrap, and ammo, but was always dying for fuel and money. I would love to try the combat training but at $80 I don't think I ever had that much money to my name the whole game, let alone have $80 to spare!Overall fun game, I put my friends' names in the spots and took pictures of the messages as I played and sent the messages to them over text. They got a kick out of it and consequently have all purchased the game. Good game, minor balance tweaks and it would be PERFECT!

Posted: January 26, 2016
												I was on the fence about recommending this one, but in the end I decided to give it a thumbs-up.Pros:- Easy to learn. If you've played The Oregon Trail, you can play this.- Retro graphics. No need for a top-end video card.- Ability to give your party funny names.- Very addictive.- You have to allocate resources carefully or you're out of luck.Cons:- What the heck is Clements' Quest?- There's game-breaking bug at the final boss.- No "back to menu" button when setting up a new game.The game is also very random, just like the original Oregon Trail. Personally, I didn't have a problem with it.

Posted: February 7, 2016
												Did you like the Apple IIe version of Oregon Trail? Did you REALLY like it? I mean, would you enjoy going to the Internet Archive and booting it up in your web browser right now?If you answered yes (or "what part of 'yes' don't you understand? STOP ASKING ME ALREADY") to these questions, just buy this game and start playing it. It's a professionally-made send-up: great pixel art, great UI, great mix of trek choices and side missions/mini-games..all mixed with the ridiculously random, unfair party happenings you expect from the journey. (Wait, did you say CRAVE from the journey? Weirdo...) As in, "Dysentery AGAIN?! Come ON!"Also, it has gamepad support. I played this with my 360 pad, seated comfortably using Steam's Big Picture Mode. It was glorious. Oh, and it's a post-apocalyptic world full of zombies; no squirrels or rabbits to shoot. Didn't mean to bury the lead, I just don't usually write reviews and I'm not really focused right now. This game rocks, I'm gonna go play it some more...

Posted: February 6, 2016
												Many gamers my age remember playing Oregon Trail in elementary school where most of us were massacred by natives or crushed by wagon wheels and 3rd world diseases. I pitty those who hadn't because such experiences have made such a game as Organ Trail even more humurous to play.Fashioned in the manner of ancient Atari games they don't interfere with the sheer absurdity players are sure to experience in this hilarious post-apocalyptic road trip across the United States in a station wagon. An obvious play on the caravans of Oregon Trail. Here, players can create several members of their party to tag along with during their journey through swarms of zombies, camps of survivors and trips through the wilderness for supplies.Don't hesitate to pick up this game if you're interested after my explanation because you will find near endless entertainment.

												Do you like Oregon Trail? Do you like Zombies? Do you like retro pixel art? Do you have a sense of humor? This game is perfect for you then! I love that you drive a station wagon instead of a stage coach/wagon *wink wink* Best moment I had went like this,  character named Eve died halfway through, so I wrote on her epitaph: Ribs are delicious. Biblical reference with the knowledge that zombies would eat my rib-woman. New character get's halfway through the campaign, & the game says, "You see something off the side of the road, investigate?" So I do & it's Eve's epitaph. My jaw dropped, & then Eve's zombified hand burst out of the ground! I had a matter of seconds to kill her. My mind was blown by having to have killed the zombie of my former character.

Posted: December 21, 2015
												I won't lie, Organ Trail might not be the best game you could grab for $5. But if you see it on sale, it's worth it. I'm not sure if my game time is accurate (almost positive it's at least double or tripple 1.7 hours) because I played it a lot offline.Anyways, as you probably already know, this is a zombie game where you manage a group and their resources. I could explain the game mechanics but honestly it would probably be faster to just watch a video or take a look at the screenshots on Steam.Overall it's fun, addicting, and challenging. Beating it for the first time was an enormous relief. Also, if you name the characters after friends/family, it adds a whole new level. You start getting attached to them and when one dies, it's actually a bit sad. It's crazy how this small little zombie game can actually suck you in and will quickly make you realize that a zombie outbreak would not be fun!

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Oh man, this game is awesome.Together, with my trusty companions: Banana, Ann, sux, and <3, we went to travel from the east coast to the west coast, trying to get through hordes of zombies and the occasional jackass kids taking advantage of the situation. We didn't make it. <3 Died pretty early because she was bit by a zombie so I had to kill her before she became a threat to the rest of us. We also encountered like 4 towns with no ammo in a row. Bad luck, I guess.BUT, WHO CARES ABOUT THE LIVES OF THOSE FOOLS ANYWAY? The game is great. I'm sure you're familiar with Oregon Trail, a timeless classic of a family escaping to the west. Well this game is that game, but much more hilarious, with obvious nods to the original. I mean, there's a boss battle with a zombie bear for starters. You also need to fix your Station Wagon from time to time. And ♥♥♥♥ing tires are always getting stolen or broken. God. I lost like 8 tires in less than half the total route. The game is terrifically fun, though. Despite it not being super action packed, the game offers a lot of decisions. And it's decisions that make someone a good gamer at the end of the day, right? I mean, do you want to rest up your team or try to get along to the next town at 30% health? What if you get intercepted by a biker gang for the 30th time? That could be unfortunate. Oh, or what if there's a horde of zombies that you can't avoid because your tire broke again? You just never know what kind of sillyness can happen, so you have to be prepared. But don't be too prepared, because there's tons of bandits who like to steal mufflers which you stocked up on because it seems like something to stock up on... but you never did need to replace any. Oh yeah, and you should totally buy food, maybe you should sell those mufflers you got from that last town for helping a family survive a shoot out or whatever was going on, you didn't read the job description, you just wanted to get paid. Oh. You can't sell those? Oh. Oh. Oh...At least you get to kill zombies and survive until your wagon reaches the west coast somewhere.

Posted: April 28, 2013
												Organ Trail: Director's Cut is a nice little reimagining of the original Oregon Trail set in a contemporary zombie appocalypse. The story is to get to a settlement on the West Coast while managing gas, food, ammo, and the lives of your four party members. The graphics and sounds are very retro, but don't feel like they're just hopping on the "because retro" bandwagon. The controlls really suck (you have to drag your mouse back to shoot forward,) which is a cumbersome carryover from the iPhone version. If this sounds appealing to you, then definitely pick it up; it's only $5 at the time of this review and it's worth it for a lazy afternoon.

Posted: April 11
												A fun diversion with a surprising amount of depth. Accurately captures the feel and fun of the original, without any of the jankiness or obtuse mechanics so synonymous with early PC gaming. Not a must play, but a solid gift or way to spend several afternoons.

Posted: December 24, 2016
												Organ Trail is a game that revisits the classic Oregon Trail game, which was originally released back in 1971. This game takes  place in an Apocalyptic world, where zombies now rule after a nuclear war has struck most of America. Your goal is to make it to the west coast safe haven with all of your party members safely. This game's mechanics stay fairly true to the original Oregon Trail game, easily making it a point of nostalgia for those old enough to remember it. For those who are too young to have experienced this game, it is still very worthwhile to pick up. While traveling to the west coast you must monitor your car's health, your food supply and of course your friend's health. You can stop on the road to scavange for food while dodging between zombies, and meet various NPCs.While stopping at towns you can do jobs that will grant you more money or supplies. These range anywhere from going to retrieve an item in a field to defending another party from zombies. And of course no Oregon Trail like game would be complete without your party members getting dysentary atleast once! Luckily this game gives you plently of times to contract this disease. Overall I would definitely reconmend this game. It is really nice for those days when you are without internet and need something to do, or you're on a road trip with a laptop.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												How can I explain how much I enjoy this game? I know! I bought it twice. Yes, bought twice. First time on iOS when it first came out, then again on Steam about a week after I joined. And I was glad to do it.Organ Trail isn't original; it's an homage. It's a bizarre, hilarious, utterly enjoyable take on the classic Apple IIe Oregon Trail. You remember: the one where everyone died of dysentery and you were left wondering just what the heck a "wagon tongue" was. Well, you trade in the Conestoga wagon for a station wagon (which bears a strong resemblance to Clark Griswold's Family Truckster, or possibly a Plymouth Reliant K) and instead of hunting buffalo, you're shooting zombies. The sound, graphics, and gameplay are all so close to the original Oregon trail that you're going to have elementary school flashbacks. (Since they have such a sense of humor, clicking in-game buttons has a sound effect: the distinctive CLUNK of a IIe keyboard.) The one and ONLY one slight ding against it is the repair minigame, but you know, that's totally forgiveable. Just because it's not my cup of tea doesn't mean it was a bad design choice or really a problem with the game. Every game has a feature or two you're not particularly fond of. Tremendous replay value, practically guaranteed hilarity, and outstanding minigames. And, of course, dysentery.

content:
Posted: January 26
												>Names characters Mr. Clean, Bob, Bib, Baaaaawwwb, and Nancy.>Baaaaawwwb instantly gets killed by bandits. Mr. Clean prompty raises the food rations.>Nancy is mercy killed after becoming infected.>Bib is killed by Mr. Clean for making annoying sounds.>Mr. Clean slowly morphs into a zombie killing machine. On a regular basis, he goes out scavenging for supplies and cleansing the world of zombies. He seldom misses his targets.>Bob becomes infected. Mr. Clean, determined to keep his last remaining companion alive, provides Bob with as many medkits as possible. Alas, Bob gradually declines in health and becomes incapitated. Mr. Clean, knowing Bob will soon turn, regretfully kills him.>Mr. Clean, the last of the group, carries on, living a life of killing zombies and scavenging for supplies as he is tormented by the deaths of his only friends. The isolation weighs heavily on him. Supplies slowly begin to run low.>At the Southwest, the station wagon breaks down once again. Mr. Clean's health is critically low. Ammo and fuel is running short and will not be replenished any time soon. He knows he will never make it to the Safe Heaven. He gets out of the station wagon for one last scavenging; his last stand against the zombies. He faces the massive horde of zombies, fearless of what he knows will happen next.>Here lies Mr. Clean. Clean at last.

												You should really play this game if you're a big fan of Oregon trail. I've only done a few runs and I can't decide if this is a "must buy" or not. The gameplay is quite lacking but it does carry a message behind it which I wont share. The zombie theme isn't doing the game much good but I guess its an alright theme. Its not a game for people who want a fast paced zombie survival game but instead some sort of reminder of what used to be the coolest thing ever.Buy this? I'd only buy this for adults who sometimes want to feel nostalgic but might need a change of theme. (If that makes any sense)
